characters: INT. IGRAYNE'S BEDCHAMBER, TINTAGEL CASTLE- EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. The sound of battle cries and the clang of meta upon metal. The forest lights up with huge sparks flying  from sword and ax as armored knights hack and swing at ea other. Mounted knights collide head-on at full gallop, th armor made incandescent in the clash. Sparks eddy in thei wakes and float to the ground. The forest catches fire. MAIN TITLES on the flames. Out of the sounds of ancient b grows music, heroic and barbaric, shot through with  melancholy. Two crazed eyes reflect the fire. The eyes belong to a ma without age, at once ancient and boyish, female and male; his eyes are pained from the burden of too much knowledge So close is he to the flames that a lock of his wild hair sizzles alight. He slaps at the fire as if it were an ann insect. He wears a cloak of black trimmed with silver. It Merlin. The wizard weaves a path through the burning fore dodging the combatants, searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Uther! Lord Uther!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest around him weeps softly with the sounds that f slaughter. Patches of undergrowth are smoldering. Small f lick bark and branches. Smoke floats through the trees and hovers over the bodies the dying and the dead. A huge knight reins up beside Merlin on a lathered horse. His armor is blood spattered. He is weary from battle. He looks down at Merlin, his countenance fierce. The blade o his sword glows with an unnatural aura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's done. A truce. We meet at the  river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Talk. Lovers murmuring to each  other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting on one bank of a small river that flows through t forest is a warlord, the Duke of Cornwall. He is flanked his armored warriors. Lot of Lowthean prominent among the They are battle-weary and bloodied, but they look ready t fight. Behind them is an army of lesser knights. To the opposite bank come Uther and Merlin, a much smalle force of knights, including Uryens, Lord of Gore, surroun them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spit on your truce, Uther. If you  want peace, throw down your swords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther and the Duke of Cornwall glare at each other in sil across the river. Uther strains forward, burning with ang but Merlin restrains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should butcher all and every one  of them. Merlin, what is this wagging  of tongues?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just show the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther unsheathes his mighty sword, and brandishes it in t air high over his head. The blade hums disquietingly and  leaves a lingering electric hue upon the air. The marvel  instills dread in all present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waxing eloquent) Behold the sword of power, Excalibur.  Before Uther, it belonged to Lud,  before Lud, to Beowulf, before Beowulf  to Baldur the Good, before Baldur to  Thor himself and that was when the  world was young and there were more  than seven colors in the rainbow. (and in an aside to  Uther) Speak the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing) One land, one king! That is my peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of Cornwall looks around nervously as some of hi knights fall to their knees in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Uther, if I yield to the sword  of power, what will you yield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, yield!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin urges Uther hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) He has given. Now you must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two knights glare at each other, rage contending with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The land from here to the sea is  yours if you will enforce the King's  will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemies lock eyes and Merlin watches anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men from both sides break out in wild cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lord King Uther, let us feast  together. To my castle. Lord Merlin,  you must join -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Merlin is nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drums and wailing flutes fill the banquet hall with a lus rhythm. Armored warriors watch a lone woman dancing. She very beautiful, both sensuous and innocent. Uther sits at the long table beside the Duke of Cornwall  with the barons and dukes of the land, and the lesser kni The table is stained with wine and littered with bones an half-eaten fruit. Uther's eyes burn with lust as he watches the dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would wish you such a wife, Lord  Uther, as my Igrayne. So innocent,  but in bed, a furnace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke rises and goes to his wife, be-striding the cent of the hall and Igrayne weaves circles of dance around hi He gloats with pride. The words escape his lips:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot spins to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You're mad! What about the  alliance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious) I must have her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And risk all you've won? This castle  commands the sea gate to the kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther is not one for politics, and Lot's words sail past  him. The King lusts for Igrayne. A bell is struck not far away. The music ceases and the h falls silent. The great door creaks open, revealing the d light, and a monk steps into the hall and waits by it. Mu by corridors of stone, a choir of monks can now be heard  singing the high, ecstatic harmonies of the Te Deum. Thos who have fallen asleep at the table are roused, those dru helped up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monk leads the party down the hallway of the castle.  Thin shafts of dawnlight filter through archers' slits in the thick walls onto stone floors. Otherwise, it is dark. Each person, lady and knight, proceeds alone, head bent,  some crossing themselves. Uther is among them. He stops in a dark alcove, breathing heavily, waiting. As the lovely Igrayne drifts past him, he pulls her out o sight of the others. In a shaft of pale light Uther clasps Igrayne to his  breastplate, his iron arm wrapped around her frail body. violent is his embrace that she cannot breathe, her mouth wide with fear, and her feet do not touch the ground; an  impaled butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be mine. Wife and queen,  bed and crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is close to hers, looking as though he would dev her tender whiteness with his kiss. She doesn't answer; s can't. Even Uther understands this and lets her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a fierce whisper) I want no other crown and no other  bed than those I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gown and her fragile skin torn on the spikes of his a Igrayne backs away and joins the procession. Uther trembles with unreleased passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne enters the candlelit chapel from which issues the chant, calling the castle to worship. She rushes to her  husband's side, kneeling next to him and whispering. The  Duke of Cornwall looks back at Uther, hatred in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther is in a towering rage. Sword drawn, he stalks among the biers of fallen knights. Squires and clerics keep a  healthy distance. The sky is lowering, pregnant with roll thunder. Beyond his encampment, high on a cliff rising ou of the sea stands the impregnable Tintagel Castle, seat o the Duke of Cornwall, now under siege.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing in all  directions) Merlin! Where are you!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then a knight rides up and dismounts. It is Ulfius, lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he cannot finish. He is taken aback by the sudden  appearance of a hideous hag who approaches, rattling a  beggar's pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a hurry you were in this morning,  good sir. You forgot to give this  old woman a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you half a day's gallop from  here. I asked you if you had seen  Merlin. I returned here straight  away. How did -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I heard. I have come. I am also  Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure straightens, the filthy rags become a flowing  cape, and the hair is swept back by the wind, andГіit is  Merlin, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have walked my way since the  beginning of time. Sometimes I give,  sometimes I take. It is mine to know  which, and when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) Dumb riddles, Merlin. I am your King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulfius edges away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the storm inside you, and  what it has wrought. The alliance I  forged is wrecked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of Cornwall under siege. All this for lust. Self lust. Uther grabs Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Igrayne. One night with her. Do  it. Use the magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin frowns pensively, his gaze searching strange dista and wandering; then focusing, blazing straight at Uther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will swear by your true kingship  to grant me what I wish. Then you  shall have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther kneels and draws his sword and holds it up by the b a cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear it. By Excalibur and the  holy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --What issues from your lust will be  mine. Swear it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin looks down sorrowfully at the kneeling King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of Cornwall watches a force of armored knights r forth from Uther's war camp, with banners flying. It pass beneath the castle and on toward a distant cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a lieutenant) It's Uther and all his best knights.  He leaves behind little more than  fledglings to guard his camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are as cold and as pale as ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther and his knights, and Merlin on a mule, ride to the  high promontory and dismount. Here, overlooking the sea, a circle of ancient stones, carved with strange runes and hieroglyphics, and as the wind moves through them it moan and sighs. The knights watch as Merlin and Uther, leading his horse, walk toward the stones. Merlin strides into the circle,  turning to look at Uther, who hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther starts to make the sign of the cross, but Merlin ha him with a gesture. Uther's hand drops, and he enters the circle with his horse. Merlin and Uther look out across the sea, to Tintagel Cas high upon the cliff. Merlin solemnly raises his arms toward that distant castl and chants in an ancient language, the sounds of which he marries to the roaring and whining of the wind. The wind  becomes stronger, and Merlin's incantations become more  intense, and the wind in turn becomes wilder still. Until Merlin is charged with a fierce, nonhuman power, as the w buffets his slight frame. And then, for all to understand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hold the balance of all things in  my summoning. Arise mists. Come fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the horizon a front of fog advances toward the castl to envelop it, and continues across the gulf to the circl of stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The portal opens and a small force of armored men, led by the Duke of Cornwall, exits. A fog is thickening all arou them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The advancing front envelops Merlin and Uther, eddying ar the stones.  All else is obliterated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mount your horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride straight to the castle, across  the sea of fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther spurs straight for the edge of the cliff, then rein in his horse abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the cliff, the sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin rages, crazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride across! Across the bridges of  desire. Your lust will hold you up.  For I have just woven it into the  fabric of the world. This is magic -  making solid what is in the mind,  and unsolid, that which is already  solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the horse a stinging blow with his staff. The horse and Uther charge forward into a gallop and step off where the hidden edge of the cliff would be, hoofbeat ceasing and the horse dropping for the blink of an eye, t gallop across the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galloping on no visible terrain, Uther and his horse adva through the restless fog, and as they recede rider and an become a wavering, changeable form within the cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse and rider pull up at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Wake up in there. It is I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was not for the electric blue hue burning in the ey of the man entering the castle, the same magic hue that  Excalibur left upon the air when wielded, the resemblance the Duke if Cornwall would be perfect. After a moment the portal opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes into an inner court, the portal closing behind. Armed men emerge cautiously. Thinking that it is their Du they help him dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the horse ready. I ride out  before sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inner gate opens and the 'Duke' goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real Duke and his men ride through the fogbound camp, cutting the ropes of the tents, stabbing the men trapped  beneath the canvas. When a frightened crow flies squawkin into the face of the Duke's horse, which rears. He is unh and falls, and impales himself on a tent stake. Dying, the true Lord of Tintagel Castle rises and stagger forward, blood pumping from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little girl of four awakens from a nightmare, a small l figure in her canopied bed. Her eyes are ice, like her  father's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa... Papa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne is soon at her side, lifting the child from the b holding her tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father is dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'Duke' enters. The room is empty, but the door to  Morgana's room is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'Duke' stands in the doorway. Igrayne herself is  surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, here is your father. It was  just a dream, little one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come Igrayne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne kisses Morgana, tucks her in and returns to her o room, closing the door. The child doesn't know whether to believe the truth of the dream or the waking truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In full armor, the 'Duke' bears down on the naked Igrayne her marriage bed. She stares at him, wondering. But his e are closed, and finally he carries her in his wild passio her white limbs tangling around the lustre of his armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Merlin is jolted awake from deep within himself, comi out of a trance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is done. The future has found  root in the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts himself up on his staff. He stands in the midst the ancient stones, bristling with excitement. Uther's mi knights are asleep, a deep unnatural sleep, huddled toget and surrounded by their horses. And then Merlin swoons,  collapsing to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lieutenants deposit the Duke of Cornwall's bloodless  body upon the long table. His eyes are wide open, icy and cunning even in death. The ladies of the castle support a comfort the grief-stricken Igrayne as she approaches the  body of her husband. Morgana hangs onto her mother's gown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did it happen? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the camp of Uther, my lady, just  after nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be. He came to me, to his  bed, last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was his spirit, yearning for you  in his hour of death, that visited  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His spirit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pale with grief, Igrayne stares at her dead husband in  silence. Then her hand drifts to her stomach. When she talks again undone and resolved, it is to all and herself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tintagel Castle falls to Uther. But  what shall become of me, and the  child I bear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana shows no distress. She runs her baby hands across her father's face and closes his eyes. The intensity that was frozen in them is now added to her own pale and cunni eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin has been propped up against one of the stones. He in a deep trance and Uther is attempting to shake him awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want her, Merlin. I cannot be  without her. Tintagel is mine. Can I  take her now? Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin's eyes open but he sees nothing, and only a puzzli squeal issues from him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. IGRAYNE'S BEDCHAMBER, TINTAGEL CASTLE- EVENING
dialogues.text: Morgana watches from a corner. The ladies of the castle  surround Igrayne who is giving birth. Noisy crows alight on the windowsill. Only Morgana notice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther strides to Igrayne's bedchamber, his warrior knight following. He is dirty and his iron dress is blood-spatte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Three horses died under me, so hard  did I spur them here. Is it born? Is  it alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his approach and entrance the ladies shrink back, and  Morgana edges closer to her mother, and seats herself on bed beside her. Ingrain holds her newborn baby in her arm the blood of birth still wet upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies slip past him to the door, and he goes up to  Igrayne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrified of him, Igrayne faces him the best she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy, sir. Rest yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther waves away her words but does sit down on the bed,  exhausted. He notices Morgana, who stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send the girl away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is just a child -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne draws the child to her and kisses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Go now. Come back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child leaves silently, hatred in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches me with her father's  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grasps the newborn baby with his iron hand, and pulls to himself. He looks upon it with wonder, with a gentlene that is unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne, is he mine, or -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't bring himself to say his name. She hesitates on edge of tears, worried for the infant lying in its iron  cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night he died, a man loved me  with great fierceness. He looked  like my husband, spoke like, smelled  like, felt like my own husband. But  it was not he, for he was already  dead. It wasn't his spirit, for this  child, who was conceived that night,  is flesh and blood. I know nothing  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther draws a dagger. He lifts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he uses it before Igrayne can move. He severs the lea thongs that bind the iron breastplate to his chest. He ca it to the floor. His chest is smooth and milk-white in  striking contrast to his creased, weathered face. And bea he holds the baby to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through him, I will learn to love  them, for I am tired of battle. I  will stay by his side and (looking shyly at  Igrayne) his mother's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne's hatred for the man is at the very edge of becom love. The baby starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. It's hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his free hand opens her shift, and he holds a swollen breast in his gloved hand, squeezing gently. Milk bubbles from it and he thrusts the baby's mouth onto it. Igrayne weeps and Uther watches proudly as the baby suckl Merlin advances from the window, his cape the same irides green-black as the feathers of the crows that were perche by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin! Out of the sick sleep at  last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what I did for you, it wasn't  easy, you know. It takes it's toll.  It took nine moons to get back my  strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther avoids looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you must pay me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child is mine, Uther. I have  come for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther is shaken to his roots. Igrayne watches, trying to  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oath. You didn't say--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't ask!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther, is it true? Don't let him  take the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swore an oath, Igrayne. I made a  pact with Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igrayne suddenly understands. She glares at Uther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you? You came to me that night.  You are the father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther is caught, and turns to Merlin who is harsh and  unswaying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for you, Uther, hearth and  home, wife and child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To kill and be king, is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not even that, Uther. I thought  once that you were the one to unite  the land under one sword. But it'll  take another, a greater king...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You strike me with words as hard as  steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are not weapons, my friend, but  truths. You betrayed the Duke, stole  his wife and took his castle, now no  one trusts you. Lot, Uryens, your  allies will turn against you. Give  me the child, Uther, I will protect  him. Go back to your war tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther wrenches the baby from it's mother's breast and han him to Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in torment) By the oath, take the devil child.  Take him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the bawling baby under his cape, Merlin exits. Igray pulls herself out of the bed, weak, her legs giving under her. She starts after Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHY?... Why must he have the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther stops her with his bulk and she claws savagely at h chest to get past him. He weeps as he folds his arms arou her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Merlin walks through the castle, the baby crying in hi arms, the knights and ladies step back, afraid to interve in royal matters. INT. HALL, TINTAGEL CASTLE - NIGHT. Merlin comes across the empty banquet hall, cooing to the baby, strangely pacifying him. Morgana steps out of the  shadows in his path, and Merlin stops at the sight of the little girl, her pale eyes glaring at him. She speaks haltingly and clearly while far-off Igrayne cr out her distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, are you now the father, and  the mother, of the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at her, Merlin shudders and without answering he  continues away, faster now, and into an unlit passageway, disappearing from sight a bit sooner than an ordinary mor would have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest is dark and shiny with rain. An unseen battle  rages. The first combatant in sight is Uther, who swings the mig Excalibur, cutting an attacker in half at the waist. Uthe and a small force of knights, Ulfius among them, are  retreating through the slippery wet forest, completely  outnumbered. Lord Lot of Lowthean and Lord Uryens of Gore are the lead of the attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) The King's sword. I must have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulfius and his men stand their ground so the King may esc the onslaught. They are hacked down. Uther flees alone, severing the limbs of any man and tree that stands in his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther has gained on his pursuers. He comes to a small cle where the spine of a buried boulder rises through the for floor. He stops upon it, breathing hard, dripping blood. rages aloud, but his throat is raw and cracked and only a whisper comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, where are you? To weave a  mist, to hide us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears his pursuers closing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one shall have the sword. No one  shall wield Excalibur but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds it by the hilt with both hands, the blade pointi to the ground of stone. He flexes his knees. He lifts up hands above his head. And with all the strength that rage and pain can muster, and more, he drives the blade of  Excalibur into the stone, nearly to the hilt. His mouth w in an awful silent scream, and then the foam of saliva pi with blood issues from deep within him, so violent was hi effort. As the sword cuts into the rock, the earth shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest quakes. The knights searching for Uther halt i fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And far away, a caped figure is crossing a field toward a wood, when the earth shakes, stirring animals and birds. man turns. He is Merlin, the two day-old baby peeking fro his cape. Merlin is amazed at the phenomenon, he puts his ear to a rock protruding from the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the spine of the dragon! (and then he is  saddened) Uther... I loved you, mighty child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tears welling, and giggling at the same time, he whis away into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uther staggers away, colliding with trees, staggering,  crashing to the ground. Until the only life left in him i the coursing of his blood, flowing from his gaping mouth  onto the leaves on the forest floor. The enemy knights advance through the trees. They prod at the fallen leviathan, they roll him over to get at his  scabbard. Only then do they see the sword in the stone, a they stop, amazed and afraid. Their captains appear. Urye sees what they are staring at, and races to the sword and attempts to pull it out. He strains with all his might, but it is immovable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Uryens aside, but he can't loosen the sword eit and he rages with frustration.

dialogues.speaker: LEGEND APPEARS
dialogues.text: "Fifteen years passed and the land was without a king."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peasants spill over the crest of a hill. They are fleeing force of armored knights, their plumed helmets forged in semblance of predatory animals. The knights thunder past peasants, trampling the ripening crops. Sir Uryens is the leader, his hard face indifferent to the havoc he leaves his wake. The peasants watch in mute anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Lot leading another group of mounted knights comes  galloping into a small hamlet, panicked chickens and pigs scattering at their approach. The farmers run for their l as the steel men dismount, leading their horses to water hay, and searching for vittles. A knight spots a woman wh stands frozen with fear, and he drags her into the barn a her crying child watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A farmhouse is burning nearby, and three mounted figures  make their way along a trail at a walking pace - an old k in leather and mail, a young knight proud in gleaming new armor; and on a farm horse, a squire with baggage and jou lance. The old knight, Sir Ector, is troubled by what he  sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a dark hour... everywhere  lawlessness and destruction, and no  one to lead us out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, ten crazed peasants emerge from the darkness,  hurling stones and armed with clubs and pronged sticks. T surround the three riders. Sir Ector wheels around and sl the air with his sword to ward off the ambushers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen all. I am Sir Ector of Morven  and these are my sons. You would  wrong me, for I have never stolen  from others, or destroyed the fruit  of the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peasants edge closer, working up the nerve to rush th horsemen. The sound of thundering hooves cuts through the clamor. A cavalcade of riders, armor gleaming in the moonlight,  advances across the fields at a gallop. Immediately the  peasants scatter. The old knight is on the verge of tears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people's anger is just. It is  sad that for our own safety, we will  have to ride to the tournament with  these robber knights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red with the first light of day, Excalibur rests in the s as King Uther left it. The field is itched with tents, ea flying its heraldic banner. Knights and squires are  everywhere, preparing horses and armor for the joust. A b man in religious robes harangues the crowd, vying for  attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Easter day, when Christ rose  again. Who will find strength in  victory of arms? Who will draw the  sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop goes among the tents, through the teeming thro solemnly casting holy water upon man and horse, armor and banner. The knights kneel at the Bishop's transit, but  ceremony does not lift the air of grimness that lies over the event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their armor ablaze with sunlight, two mounted knights thu toward each other at full gallop, lowering their long jou lances. As they meet, the lance of each knight is deflect by the shield of the other. A gasp goes through the crowd and the two knights charge past each other. They wheel ar at the end of the jousting ground and go at each other ag from the other direction. Again lances strike, and this t one of the men is hit in the chest and violently unhorsed The crowd cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The victor, Leondegrance, rides up to the stone and dismo Each great knight with his coterie of lesser knights come to watch. A charge of expectation is in the air, although most knights are glowering with envy. Leondegrance of Camelyarde ascends to the sword, grabs it the hilt, and begins to tug with all his might. Excalibur immovable. The moment of tension passes. Leondegrance sta toward his waiting squires, who lead him away. All the ot return to the battle sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the jousting ground Sir Ector's son Sir Ka is getting ready for a bout. His brother Arthur is buckli the new armor while his father fusses about him, making s adjustments when he notices that Kay's scabbard is empty. turns to Arthur and grab's him by the ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, where is Kay's sword? A good  squire doesn't forget his knight's  sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fifteen year-old boy blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left it in the tent, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hurry then, and get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy dashes off as Sir Ector shakes his head, not with affection beneath the sternness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur runs in search of their tent. He finds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters. The saddle trunk has been emptied on the floor equipment is scattered all over. Arthur is shocked,  nonetheless he rummages madly. Finally he stops, on the v of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been stolen....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes out, utterly defeated, and frantic. He stops by knights who are arguing angrily; and one of them has left his sword in the grass. Arthur looks at it. He is tempted to steal it, but he can Head down, he wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ector and Sir Kay are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I'll go and see what's keeping  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stops at the edge of the dark forest, totally deje when he sees the sword in the stone. He walks up to it, h face lighting up, brimming with innocence. He is alone, a everyone has returned to the jousting ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only Kay could have it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, forgetting his troubles, a boy again living in fairy tale. He grasps the sword by the hilt and it comes  away easily from its stone lock. Not expecting it to, he nearly falls. He stares at it,  terribly excited and surprised: he tucks it under his arm and rushes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bumps into Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) Your sword was stolen, Kay, but here  is Excalibur. Is it too late? I  hurried--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay takes it. He cannot believe what he's holding in his  hands. He starts to talk but he is so agitated he can onl stutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, with Arthur in tow, rushes to Sir Ector and shows hi the sword; he trembles with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Father. Excalibur. Does that  mean that I am to be king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ector is dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you free the sword, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... did, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ector looks at his son amazed, wanting to believe but not able to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must go to the stone at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Excalibur in hand Ector of Morven heads for the ston Kay following, and Arthur too, the boy flushed with excit but a little worried, not understanding what is happening The exchange between Sir Ector and Sir Kay has been overh Some have seen the sword in Sir Ector's hand. Rumor sprea like wildfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sir Ector ascends the stone, from all parts of the jou ground knights and squires, the Bishop and the clerics, a peasants too, press around. Ector lowers the blade into the tight cleft and Excalibur sinks to its original position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw it, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Kay grabs the hilt and pulls without conviction, and sword doesn't give. Eyes downcast, he lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I didn't draw the sword. Arthur  gave it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur ?! (spinning around to  face him) How did you get the sword, child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Sir... Kay needed a sword. His was  stolen. I saw Excalibur, and... I  took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You freed it, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, Father. I beg your forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to kneel but Ector pulls him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the sword, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is about to grasp the hilt when Uryens and Lot, an other nobles, Leondegrance of Camelyarde, and Sir Caradoc and Sir Turquine among the younger, stride up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, Sir Ector, and take your  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens, Lot, Leondegrance, Caradoc, Turquine - each in tu grapples with the sword, only to be defeated by its  immobility. The crowd around the stone is thickening with common folk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the boy try the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the boy try...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The demand is echoed by peasants and serfs. The great kni remain silent and bitter in their defeat. Sir Ector pushe Arthur to the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, boy. Don't be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy hesitates shyly, and then takes the hilt of Excal and pulls out the sword with a great sweep. The throng is stunned. Silence falls. Some kneel, followi the example of Sir Ector and Sir Kay, of the Bishop and  Leondegrance. The other nobles stay back, confused, afrai angered. Arthur stands there, little more than a boy, his cheeks  flushed, his soft hair ruffled by the wind, his eyes shin with exultation, awe, and fear. Then, as if gaining confi from the sword itself, he turns it in arcs above his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have our King, thanks be to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commoners and some of the knights react with roaring  enthusiasm. The others draw closer to Uryens and Lot and  their supporters, closing ranks around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Father, rise up. I was your  son before I became your King... if  I am King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ector rises, tears streaming down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lord, you are King, all the more  because you are not my son, and I am  not your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is quite a shock to the boy king, and to the onlooke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Merlin brought you to  me when you were newly born and  charged me to raise you as my own.  At first, I did so because I feared  Merlin, later because I loved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin's name is on the lips of all those close by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From out of the forest strides Merlin, dramatic, cape flo eyes crazed as ever, laughing at his own entrance. A crow perched on his shoulder, and it squawks loudly. Annoyed w it, Merlin swooshes it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Merlin. Counselor to kings.  Wizard and beggar. Prophet and... (he drops it) I have feasted on thunderbolts, I  savored my death before I got myself  born. I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin interrupts himself when his eyes fall on the boy, is taking in his performance raptly, half awestruck, half amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose son am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the son of King Uther, and  the fair Igrayne... you are King  Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suspicion and confusion and envy of the lords erupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, we haven't forgotten you.  This is more of your trickery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trying to foist a boy of  dubious birth upon us. You want to  shame us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Leondegrance, join us against  the boy. Surely you can see he is  only Merlin's tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I, Leondegrance, Lord of  Camelyarde, saw the drawing of Uther's  sword, and witnessed no trickery. If  a boy has been chosen, a boy shall  be king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd of serfs and peasants cheer wildly, and their l suppressed anger against the nobles comes to the fore. Th dare to press up against them, fists hammering on their  shields as the chant Arthur King over and over. Dark and  scowling, full of rebellion, all the lords except Leondeg begin to withdraw their iron men surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bells toll the good news. People stream by to see the new king and join the celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens and Lot, and Caradoc, Turquine, and the other lord have mounted, and are moving out, when from the rear guar bowman in Lot's service draws upon the unarmored figure o Arthur across the cheering crowd. The bowman lets the arr fly. It flies over the heads of the crowd, unseen. Except by Merlin at Arthur's side. He extends his arms ha up, his fists clenched tightly as if drawing urgently on power within himself. The sound of wings is heard as he f his arms. The arrow flies toward Arthur. Arthur sees the arrow coming right at him, when a swoopin crow plucks it out of the air. Arthur watches the crow flapping its wings, climbing swif the arrow in its beak, disappearing over the forest. Only has noticed. When he turns Merlin is no longer at his side; to the  puzzlement of all. And Arthur is all of a sudden terribly alone and afraid, as people from all sides clamor for his attention and guidance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur charges through the shadowy forest. He is in armor but it is only a light tunic of mail. Excalibur is sheath in a leather scabbard by his side. He is frantic and he c urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Merlin... Merlin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face shines with sweat, the horse is lathered. He  dismounts and continues on foot into denser, more tangled undergrowth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge eye opens in the foreground of what had appeared t be shadow, bark and tufts of weeds is really Merlin's hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is thin as he is awakening from a deep, exhaust sleep. Arthur finds him lying within the large gnarled ro of a great tree. The boy kneels before Merlin and lifts h hands and kisses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved me from the arrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a flicker of mischief) But not from your destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur blurts it out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, help me. I need your help. I  don't know how--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) 'Help me, Help me.' Help me get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur helps Merlin up and the wizard stands unsteadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired. Doing magic takes its  toll, you know. My arms ache  terribly... (he makes flying  movements with his  arms and grimaces) Once--or is it yet to happen--I stood  exposed to the Dragon's breath so  that a man could lie one night with  a woman. It took me ten moons to  recover. I'm sure that story would  interest you, since... Well, we'll  have to talk about it another time.  You're too busy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest groans and creaks, alive with murmurs and shri calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is whispered in the forest that... (he cups his ear with  exaggeration) ...Leondegrance's castle is under  siege by Lot and Uryens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing) Yes, yes, I know that. Everybody  does. Lord Leondegrance is my only  ally among the barons and the great  knights. I can't lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there. You don't need me half  as much as you think you do. You  already know what must not happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) I must find the means to save him,  then. I was hoping I could ask you  for a little magic help, but if it  makes you so tired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Arthur tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I have no experience,  and no men to speak of. How can I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly fierce) Because you must! You and only you.  Have you forgotten that it was you  who freed Excalibur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as suddenly, he is his amused, ironic self again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, it will be a good lesson. (giggling) The best, if it's not the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur bows his head, confused and almost defeated. Merli steals a look at him, and puts his arm around the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd like to meet the power  that gave you the sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enjoys being cryptic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the great book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What book is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (melodramatic) The book without pages. Open before  you, all around us. You can see it  in bits and pieces, for if mortal  men were to see it whole and all  complete in a single glance, why, it  would burn him to cinders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon! There...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deep cleft at the edge of the forest, where far below l boils with a phosphorescence that lights up a great cloud billowing upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coiled in the unfathomed depths, it  emerges...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin points to the sky where roiling clouds appear to b unfurling of immeasurable wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It unfolds itself in the storm  clouds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrific wave batters a coastline, spray shooting up, a as the wave recedes it exposes dark rocks and deep crevic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it washes its mane sparkling white  in the blackness of seething  whirlpools...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin spins Arthur around, and they are transported into storm swept forest. Lightning strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...its claws are the forks of  lightning... its scales glisten in  the bark of trees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees shine with wetness, as a great wind tosses thei crowns, the branches groaning against each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...its voice is heard in the  hurricane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is awestruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Merlin are back in the same spot, having in fa never moved at all, but traveled on the spell of Merlin's words alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it is so much more than a scaly  monster. It is Everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's eyes shine with the brilliance of the vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I am to be King of everything,  lord and commoner, beast, leaf and  rock, I must use its voice, its claws,  its power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leondegrance, Lord of Camelyarde, is shocked by what he s in the distance. His daughter Guenevere, a beautiful girl sixteen, draws close to him, terrified. With his survivin knights, Leondegrance is making his last stand. The walls have been breached, parts of the castle are burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bellowing dragon advances. Its eyes burn, its scales gl from light shining from within. It snorts fire from its  nostrils. Uryens and Lot, Caradoc and Turquine, the great knights i command of the siege of Leondegrance's castle, back away  speechless as the monster descends upon their unprepared camp. All around them, squires and lesser knights flee in panic and confusion. Only a dozen or so remain with their leaders. The group b up against the swampy moat that surrounds the castle, wai with swords drawn. The dragon moves closer, and now it becomes apparent that is nothing more than a force of knights and footmen. Thei shields glinting in the moonlight are the dragon's scales torches its burning eyes. And the snorting flames from it nostrils are only Merlin doing a fire-eater's trick. The dragon form dissolves, and a banner rises bearing the emblem of the Dragon, and under it, Arthur and Ector and lead a charge of twenty knights. In Arthur's hands, Excalibur leaves an electric glow upon the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, it's the boy King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. I will fight my way to his  side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and his men charge into the enemy ranks. Lot's and Uryens' people are pushed into the moat. Although the wat is only waist-deep, the fallen, weighed down by their arm drown. The horses of the attackers are brought down, Arth among them. He pulls out from under it, limping. Bleeding form wounds, cutting, slashing, thrusting, he falls back  from the havoc of the charge. A small distance exists now between the foes, a brief res Uryens and Lot, exhausted, bleeding, and fierce in their  rage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War-wise fighters, grown gray in  battle, checkmated by a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Merlin's trickery, nothing more.  I won't swear faith to that wizard's  brat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and his men have been joined by Leondegrance and h knights, few in number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's finish this with a show of  force. We have no more tricks and no  more advantages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes alone at the enemy, shouting at the top of his  lungs, Excalibur flashing over his head, prepared to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere watches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Arthur--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old knight rushes after the boy, sword drawn, to defe his flank, and the others follow, a battle cry issuing fr them that is terrifying in its fierceness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and when she can't watch any longer, she buries her fa in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur fights like a wounded lion at the center of the sa melee of sword and shield, and once again the two sides f apart. Uryens and Lot are standing in the moat among the bodies their men, are reduced to eleven knights, all wounded. Arthur is flanked by twenty men at arms, most of them wou and trembling now beyond exhaustion with blood lust. Arth steps forward alone, and addresses his opponents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in my hands, to slay or spare.  I need battle lords such as you.  Swear faith to me and you shall have  mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noble knights swear faith to a mere  squire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur turns, searching for Merlin. He spots him watching from a distance. They stare at each other, Merlin implaca Arthur's eyes pleading. It's obvious that Merlin isn't go to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right. I'm not yet a knight. (gaining strength) You, Uryens, will knight me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unsheathes Excalibur and goes forward, kneeling before Uryens and offering him the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then as knight to knight I can offer  you mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) What's this, what's this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, kneeling, bows his head and Uryens steps up to hi his features set. He accepts the sword. Lot watches, a ma hope dancing in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere watches, frightened for Arthur, not daring to  breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens stands towering above the boy. He smiles enigmatic He lifts Excalibur. Merlin is attempting to push through the crowded ranks to get to Arthur. He's frantic and worried for once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens swiftly lowers the sword on Arthur's neck; with th flat of the blade he gives Arthur the three strokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of God, of Saint Michael  and Saint George, I give you the  right to bear arms, the power to  mete justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That duty I will solemnly obey as  knight and King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens is deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise, my King. I am your humble  knight, and I swear allegiance to  the courage in your veins, for so  strong it is, it's source must be  Uther. I doubt you no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur rises and Uryens kneels and kisses his hands. Sir  Ector turns away to hide brimming tears. Merlin pushes th finally, out of breath. Uryens embraces Leondegrance whil Lot and the other enemy knights kneel in turn and kiss  Arthur's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The castle can be glimpsed through the trees. A clear spr bubbles from the ground, and the sun splashes leaf, bird, squirrel, and bee with golden light, and Arthur and Guene too. Guenevere is serious and intent on her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owww...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With water from the spring, she is bathing a large cut on his chest that has been stitched closed. Wounds on his ar and one on a calf also show evidence of her neat sewing.  She's just finishing, and she dabs his chest with a dry c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't hurt too much, did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I'm pretty good at stitchery. I've  sewn my father's wounds more than  once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful! You'll have to stay still  for a few days or you'll tear them  open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shivers at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have to leave tomorrow. The  forests are thick with rebels,  invaders plunder our shores...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --And damsels in besieged castles  are waiting to be rescued?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know Leondegrance had a  daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, I shall tell you which  knights have maiden daughters, so  you can avoid their castles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur smiles at her, enjoying her jealousy, and it irrit her a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think it's better if you just  stay here to heal. At least a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, or I'll sew up your mouth  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his lips with hers, her eyelids fluttering sh He stares at her young beauty, and draws her into a long, slow kiss. A shrill almost human squeal pierces the air not far away Arthur pulls away startled, half-rising. Guenevere giggle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rescue me from a fiery  dragon, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her arms around him, drawing him close again,  speaking in a half-whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a furry little rabbit that  took the bait and sprung the trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other, about to kiss. As they come clo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find him served up to you  tonight, cooked in a most excellent  sauce...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft beat of psaltery and the liquid flow of lute. A  serving platter bearing roast rabbit in rampant position carried across the hall. It is laid on the long raised ta before Arthur, who presides in the middle. He looks at it suspiciously and blushes, remembering the afternoon; and looks back at him accusingly with its cherry eye. Guenevere is dancing around her father, lovely, gliding,  sensual. She sees Arthur and the rabbit and laughs out-ri He twists off a leg of the rabbit and sinks his teeth int it to hide his embarrassment. Guenevere passes to another partner, smiling at him, radiant. Arthur watches her, his heart breaking. He is in love. Merlin leans close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A king must marry, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only then does he realize that Merlin has understood  everything. He is annoyed at being so transparent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love her. If she would be my queen,  my dreams would be answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mischievous) There are maidens as fair, and fairer  than Guenevere. If I put my mind to  it, I could see them now, many of  them, weeping for love of you,  watching the hills for you coming  from the high towers of their castles.  Offering you their every favor. Rich,  clever--but if it is to be Guenevere,  so be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow of doubt crosses Arthur's brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will it be? Put your mind to it,  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere. And a beloved friend who  will betray you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Guenevere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening. Your heart is  not. Love is deaf as well as blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere approaches, smiling and coquettish. She slaps h hands, and a servant sets down a tray of pastries before  Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are only for you, for in them I  mixed things that heal, but not too  quickly; and things that make limbs  sleepy, preventing escape, but keep  one's mind sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Arthur's embarrassment and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a cake and bites into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an ancient mixture, containing  only soft, unborn grains, and flavored  with roses. The rest is secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere offers one to Arthur, and he hesitates, looking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at the cake is like looking  at the future. Until you have savored  its bitterness and its sweetness,  its texture and its perfume, what do  you really know? And then, of course,  it will he too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur bites into the cake, and Guenevere looks deep into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late...

dialogues.speaker: A LEGEND APPEARS
dialogues.text: "...but for years war kept Arthur from thoughts of marria

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War tents have been pitched beneath the majestic trees. N the banner of the Dragon a doe grazes. Arthur is older, i battle-scarred plate armor, pacing and angry. He is watch by his wounded and bruised knights--Kay, Uryens, Lot,  Leondegrance, Caradoc, and some new young faces among the ranks. No one talks. The harsh clank of its battle trappings announces the arr of a horse. All eyes watch it walk into the camp. A knigh is slouched in the saddle. Arthur runs to meet the horse, followed by squires and so of the knights. He eases the rider to the ground, unlaces his helmet. It Sir Ector, and his hauberk is badly dented. Tears burn in Arthur's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the mightiest and fairest of  knights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fought and won battles, and now  one man defeats all my knights? I  will go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes past the knights and goes to his horse. Kay ste in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A king must not engage in single  contest. I'll go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur rises into the saddle and takes a jousting spear f the rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squires are silent. Arthur gallops off in the direction Sir Ector came from. knights are afraid for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His countenance grim, Arthur gallops along a trail border a plowed field when in it a scarecrow moves. It starts to run as stick-wielding farmers pursue it. It is Merlin. Ar turns off into the field, and at the sight of an armored  knight on a war horse, the farmers turn and flee. Merlin  stops to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) I should have left you to fend for  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to weave a little enchantment  on the bees so I could get some honey,  and I didn't feel up to using any  more magic just yet. Anyway, I was  in less danger than you'll be in  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's hand is clenched tight around Excalibur's hilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you were stealing their honey.  They should have killed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now. So much anger for such a  little crime? Are you sure there is  nothing else troubling you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know full well there is, and I  go to meet it now. Come witness my  revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers his arm and Merlin hoists himself up behind the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waterfall cascades into a pool. The spray casts a rainb Beneath it is a colorful confusion of flowers and budding trees, a place dreamlike in its beauty. Arthur, with Merlin behind, gallops along the edge of the pool. The trail widens into a field of grass. Arthur rein beside a pile of broken lances and twisted shields. Acros the field, pitched upon the trail is a war tent made of  diaphanous white silk, a sky blue banner above it. Merlin slides off and Arthur continues. From the tent, a knight with jousting lance rides forward meet him. His armor is so shiny it is a mirror. His eyes, seen through the open visor, seem to laugh. His speech is foreign, from across the sea. He is Lancelot of the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day to you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move aside. This is the King's road,  and the knights you joined arms  against were his very own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I await the King himself. His knights  are in need of training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am King, and this is Excalibur,  sword of kings from the dawn of time.  Who are you, and why do you block  the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Sir Lancelot of the Lake, from  across the sea. I am the best knight  in the whole of Christiandom, and I  look for the king who is worthy of  my sword's service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --That is a wild boast. You lack a  knight's humility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a boast, sir, but a curse. (a cloud passes over  his innocent face) Never have I met my match in joust  or duel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move aside!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not. You must retreat or prove  your kingship in the test of arms,  under the eyes of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then may He give me the strength to  unhorse you and send you with one  blow back across the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur wheels away, trembling with anger, and gallops to edge of the field. He sees that Lancelot has already  positioned himself and is waiting, lance down. Merlin watches, a spectator, as the two charge at each ot They collide with great force, their spears shattering. A is jolted but stays in the saddle. Lancelot's jousting is impeccable. Arthur draws Excalibur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold! I offer you another lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pages come forward with new lances for Arthur and Lancelo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joust well, sir. Battle learnt,  but tournament fancy. You should  ride more forward in the saddle,  though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur grabs the spear from the page's hands, and circles back to work the horse up into an all-out gallop. Lancelo spurs forward to meet him. Arthur is neatly unhorsed. He  picks himself up from the ground in a rage, drawing Excal Lancelot on his horse weaves circles around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yield. I have the advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur charges Lancelot, a raging bull, but cuts and slas only at the air as Lancelot stays clear of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight me from your horse or on foot,  but fight me. Your avoidance mocks  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sought only not to harm you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dismounts and draws his sword, and they clash. Shield sword and armor against shield and sword and armor. The  swordplay is furious, Arthur attacking, slashing, hacking Lancelot parrying effortlessly, elegantly defensive. Arth breaks the onslaught to catch his breath. Lancelot lifts visor. His eyes are calm, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, your rage has unbalanced you.  It seems you would fight to the death  against a knight who is not your  enemy, for a length of road you can  ride around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it, to the death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is you, sir, who knows not the  virtue of humility, as a true king  must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur goes forward attacking with terrible blows upon  Lancelot's shield, and Lancelot holds his ground, shield  high. And in its mirror-like metal Arthur can see his own reflection, a face distorted by uncontrolled passion. Arthur discards his own shield, grabs Excalibur with both hands, and with a frightening shout that speaks of all hi rage, he swings a terrific blow upon the shield, cutting  through his own reflection and the metal. And Excalibur s in two. A blinding blue-green light explodes from the broken swor Lancelot, knocked back by the force of the blow, is stunn by the blast and falls to the ground unconscious. Arthur  backs away, horrified, half of Excalibur in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What horror is this? (calling) Merlin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin approaches, pale, gripped by dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sword is broken. Hope is broken...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur picks up the broken blade, utterly undone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pride broke it, my rage broke  it... Humiliation and defeat lie in  ambush even for a king. (looking at Lancelot) This excellent knight who fought  with fairness and grace was meant to  win. With Excalibur, I tried to change  that verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin stands there, drawn, defeated, his hopes dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lost for all time the ancient  sword of my fathers whose power was  meant to unite all men, to serve the  vanity of a single man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despairing, he flings the two parts of Excalibur into the pool. He kneels at the waters edge, and he cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Arthur sees something that startles him. Beneath the surface, suspended in the blue-green water amid the danci weeds, he sees Excalibur, intact. It is held by a maiden in flowing gown the color of water her long hair rippling across her face, obscuring it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excalibur! Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lady of the Lake. Take it. Take  it, quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur dips his hand under the water and grasps the hilt the moment he does the vision in the blue-green water fad He rises with Excalibur in hand, and Merlin speaks before Arthur can ask the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are infinite worlds within the  infinite coils of the Dragon. In one  of them, which I have not traveled,  the sword was forged. I only know  that the King is returned to us  through the instrument of his power.  The game continues!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he laughs. Just then Lancelot stirs. Arthur rushes to his side. He  loosens his helmet and removes it, uncovering damp curls. The young knight's eyes open, and his laughing charm once more animates his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to God, you are alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up) I, the best knight in the world,  bested! This is a great day, for my  search is over. I love you, my King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces Arthur, who is overwhelmed by his childlike  directness. The King helps him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are still the best knight in  Christiandom. You gained a hundred  advantages over me. It is I who must  love you, for through your courage  and patience you taught me a bitter  lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then make me your champion and I  will always fight in your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your life and lands are far from  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave up my castles and my lands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thumps his breastplate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My domain is here, inside this metal  skin. And I would pledge to you all  that I still own: muscle, bone, blood  and the heart that pumps it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a great heart it is. Sir Lancelot,  you will be my champion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot draws his sword, holding it by the blade, a cruc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of Jesus Christ and His  holy blood, I swear eternal faith to  Arthur, King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace, and Merlin watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converging from different directions parties of mounted  knights enter the war camp. Lancelot among them. They  dismount, battle-weary and burning with the excitement of victory. They quench their huge thirst from buckets carri by squires. They rip off hunks of meat from carcasses siz on spits over a roaring fire. And they join the throng of knights, where stories of deeds of arms of the day are  enthusiastically exchanged. A great number of knights are packed tightly around King  Arthur, each man anxious to tell of his victories. One of them has the King's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We killed every one of them. Burnt  their ship...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sees Lancelot in the throng and moves toward him.  Merlin follows Arthur and is pushed and knocked around in the crush of spikes and iron. The only unarmored man in t crowd, he glares at the excited knights irritably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot, how did you fare in the  North?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We spared the lives of a few, so  they could sail home and tell their  fellows what fate they met at the  hands of King Arthur's knights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur turns toward Uryens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, Uryens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot, and you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drove the invaders into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Gawain, the East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The East is ours again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers greet each declaration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war is over. One land, one King.  Peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst the celebration, a fracas is heard. A knight pushi forward to talk to Arthur has entered a shoving match wit those in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me through. I fought the King's  battle too. He must know my story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin is brutally jostled. He draws a fistful of powder  from his cape and he tosses it into the air above him. He raises his staff into the cloud, cracking it like a whip. The tip of the staff catches fire, and the fire spreads  through the powder in the air, stunning all into silence. Merlin shouts and snarls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos... confusion... brutes...  savages... troglodytes... Stand  back... make space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin swings his burning staff into a wide arc. The knig back away, amused at first, then a bit afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon... the sun... the stars...  they spin... they turn... they  circle... around us... us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knights have fallen back. Merlin stalks past each man and Arthur too, holding the flaming tip of his staff befo each pair of eyes, and staring into them with his gimlet  gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, and you, and you, take up your  place. Be wedded to the world. Respect  its perfection. All of you, together,  be one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knights have formed a circle. They realize this.  Awestruck, they whisper in astonishment, looking up at th sky burning with stars. Merlin brims with pride as he wai for Arthur to recognize his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ancient wisdom and infinite  sight have forged this circle, Merlin.  Hereafter we shall come together in  a circle, to tell and hear of deeds  good and brave. I will build a table  where this fellowship shall meet.  And a hall around the table. And a  castle about the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheer rises. Arthur strides into the ring of knights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another bout of cheers goes up, and Arthur stops before  Leondegrance, resting his hand on the old knight's should

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the land will have an heir to  wield Excalibur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leondegrance's eyes fill with tears of joy. A roar of che Arthur draws the sword of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knights of the Round Table, good  friends, brothers in arms. I send  you on a quest harder by far than  the battles we have fought together,  a quest to uphold always, and  everywhere, justice, honor, and truth.  Each day shall bring forth a cause,  and may each cause bring forth a  knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot is drawn in by the King's enthusiasm. He unsheat his sword and swoops it low in salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear never to rest twice on the  same pillow till all men live at  peace.
