dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In quick succession all knights draw their swords, follow Lancelot's example. Merlin struggles to put out the flame on his staff. He fi does it by smothering it with earth. When he looks up aga he sees the knights galloping off in all directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrified women, a screaming child, cowering men, old or  made old by the hard labor of the fields. Armored men are ransacking a farm, looking for grain, and gold which they find among the votive objects of a little house altar. A  woman is dragged away to be raped. Through a window, a knight in shining armor is seen emerg from the adjoining woods. The plunderers are all of a sud apprehensive, and fall silent. One of them grabs the cryi child and covers her mouth with his iron hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knight is Lancelot, in his mirror-like armor. He ride into the cluster of houses and barns that make up the far There are other armored men there, around a cart half-loa with loot. They smile nervously at Lancelot. The farmers blank with fear. Lancelot stops in the middle of the yard. A knight among armored men comes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he also acknowledges with a nod the ashen-faced patri of the community. Lancelot spurs his horse on, and the knight sighs with re But then he reins his horse to a stop. He has sensed  something. He turns his head, his hooded eyes on the knig and his men, and they squirm inwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child, her mouth covered by the armored hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot, listening, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman, a blade flashing next to her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot, immobile. Behind him, the knight, his face shin with sweat. His minions inch forward, hands moving slowly toward sword hilts. Lancelot wheels his horse around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear the stifled cry for help, I  smell the reek of fear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a shout the knight and his men draw their swords and rush Lancelot. He reins in his horse, causing it to rear break their attack. He slides off, falling on his feet wi sword drawn, already fighting. In an extraordinary show o sword play he cuts down six men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing Lancelot storm in, the man holding the child hand her to a woman and kneels before the altar, just as Lance bursts into the room, sword high and already swooping dow on the man's neck. Lancelot brings the sword to a halt mi air, his fury held in check. The repent man is spared. Th woman kneels to kiss Lancelot's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field is pitched with war tents and pavilions decked holiday. Nobles and knights flank the King and Guenevere, beautiful vision in white samite, a wreath of flowers aro her head. Lancelot leads a long file of prisoners to the  King. They fall to their knees, begging forgiveness; amon them is the man whom Lancelot had spared before the altar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men repented before God for  their evil deeds. Those who would  not, met their fate at the end of my  sword. (he kneels) Accept the fruit of my first quest  as my wedding gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Rise, Lancelot, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and follows Arthur and Guenevere into the centra pavilion. Pages draw its curtains closed as they pass ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere is surrounded by a group of ladies and maids wh fuss over her dress and her hair. They eye the great knig and whisper about him, Guenevere laughing with them. Arthur sits, excited and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit beside me, Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot sits, stiff and upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your deeds set an example for all  other knights. For your gift, ask a  gift of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only give me leave to ride out again,  to do what I am most able to do, and  happiest doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere overhears. She approaches and Lancelot jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arthur) He must stay for the feasting days  of our wedding, and tell his deeds  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lancelot, smiling) I grant you your wish if you grant  Lady Guenevere hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will stay Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin leans close to Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knights of Galys approach the  camp. It would be politic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to ride out and meet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises. Lancelot, who was about to sit again, straighte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ride with Sir Kay. Lancelot,  rest here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start a war on my wedding day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without Lancelot?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Merlin exit, leaving Guenevere and Lancelot. S looks at him, lively and amused, and he can't help smilin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Lancelot. The maids and ladies  whisper about you. They all dream of  winning you, young and old, fair and  ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But surely that's no secret to you,  dear Lancelot. You're the bravest  and strongest knight they've ever  seen, and beauty has kissed your  brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The well-kept secret is whether any  of them has won your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a fighting man and I am married  to the quest. That is enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there is no maiden in the whole  world who inspires you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I would swear my love to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me? But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot love as a woman the lady  who will be wife to my King and my  friend. And, in pledging my love to  you, I cannot love any other woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere smiles, moved by his blunt innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see you in all women, and I  will defend them as I would defend  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels, kisses her thigh, rises and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of children sings. The Bishop waits at the altar with his friars and altar boys. Cornucopias overflowing w vegetables and wildflowers adorn the church, which glows  with the light of a thousand candles. Sir Kay is satisfie He comes back up the petal-strewn aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Guenevere are ushered in by Kay. They are flan by Leondegrance and Sir Ector. Lancelot and Merlin follow leading the cortege of knights and ladies. Merlin is incapable of entering the chapel, as if at the  threshold there is an unseen force that repels him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Merlin, are you ill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I need air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strangling a laugh he wrenches himself away. Just then Ur and a small party of knights rides up through the tents a dismounts in front of the church. Uryens helps a lady off her horse and joins the cortege on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, don't you join the  celebration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, who was slinking away through the throng of  bystanders, looks up. What he sees sends a chill through body. At Uryens' side stands a young woman of sinister beauty,  with bewitching eyes of ice. Merlin just stares at her, a she smiles back at him faintly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife, Merlin. Lady Morgana of  Cornwall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember you, Merlin. I was a child.  You took my brother away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin laughs. Uryens shrugs and continues into the chape with Morgana. As she enters she glances back, and just th Merlin steals a look, their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uryens and Morgana take their places near the altar. Arth and Guenevere kneel before the Bishop, and Arthur takes h hand. The clatter of armor mingles with the enthusiastic, happy singing of the children, and seems to strengthen th song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chorus carries across the field to the dark wall of t from which issues another chorus, of hoots and squawks an howls. Merlin advances along the edge of the forest. He s by the stone that once held the sword, his eyes wild. He  forgets his inner torment when he sees a plant at the bas of the stone. He kneels beside it and plucks it. He admir its strange flowers; he smells them. Two feet appear at his side. He rises to be face to face  with Morgana. They look deep into each other. Then Merlin breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left your husband's side? You  left your brother's wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Mandrake, Lord Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it truly be used for magic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin smiles at last, and Morgana does, her eyes piercin cruel and lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gaze drifts toward the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There are many powers in this  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Guenevere are radiant with joy, and Lancelot b them mirrors the ceremony of their joining in his armor; the sweet voices of the children fill the chapel as the B pours the wine into the chalice, and lifts it up before h blessing it. He turns to the royal couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink this the blood of Jesus Christ  our Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chalice seems to burn with a mystical light; and as t chorus soars:

dialogues.speaker: A LEGEND APPEARS
dialogues.text: "And Arthur built his castle, Camelot. And one day, in th far reaches of the Kingdom..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is shadowy and dark; ancient trees creak, unseen anima cry out. A rabbit hops into view and a boy leaps forward, grabbing the animal by the ears before it can move. He-- Perceval--is a wild boy of seventeen, dressed in skins wi an endearing and childlike smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the rabbit) Sorry. Hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A din is heard to the forest, and it grows. Perceval glan around, panicked. The sound is the rubbing of leather upo leather, of metal on metal, for now a mounted figure in a hovers over the terrified boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stuttering) Have I taken too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets the rabbit go free. The threatening figure dismou And Perceval, cartwheels backward, landing in the stream scooping a fish out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately trying  to ingratiate) I had rabbit yesterday. Today I'll  eat fish... No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns the fish to the water. The figure steps into a pool of sunlight and a glorious halo streaks from the arm It is Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval is overcome with astonishment, and he kneels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an angel! Not a devil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot laughs and pulls the boy to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a man. A knight in the King's  service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a man?! (he reaches out to  touch Lancelot) ...with metal skin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval is beside himself with enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I grow metal skin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot rolls his eyes, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a lot to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot is cantering and Perceval is running alongside,  shouting in gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll learn... take me... to the  King... What's a... King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot shakes his head and spurs the horse into a gallo Perceval lengthens his stride, and keeps up! Lancelot rei to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Climb up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, boy, it's more than twenty  days from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty days!? The world is that big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval cannot believe his eyes. As Lancelot and Kay tal about him out of earshot, he sees things that he's never  seen before; and he gapes like the country bumpkin that h is. Dragon-like kites sweep low, maneuvered by children. In a meadow among the trees, knights hone their skills with la and sword, and ladies watch and their "bright eyes rain  influence and judge the prize." And then, there is Camelo itself; the great gate and the drawbridge; the massive wa and the soaring towers and spires above. Perceval rushes up to Lancelot and Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will give me my sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay is not at all pleased; nonetheless he takes the boy b the ear and leads him across the drawbridge and into the  castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitchen knives and greasy spits will  be your weapons, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot smiles to himself, hesitation, lingering before great gate of Camelot. There is a walkway suspended in the trees above, that als leads to the castle, and promenading on it is a group of  women, Guenevere and her ladies-in-waiting. The Queen see Lancelot and hastens toward him. Lancelot sees her, and mounts his horse and heads back in the forest. She stops, somewhat ahead of the ladies, and  watches wistfully. Lancelot turns back and seeing her one last time, draws d his visor and spurs his horse into a canter. He passes two commoners who are heading for the castle, o fat and the other thin, and they are locked in hot disput Their wives keep them from coming to blows and their chil spur them on, enjoying the excitement. Lancelot is swallowed by the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere, bearing a bowl of perfect, deep red apples,  approaches the Round Table, where Arthur sits and Merlin his side, attending to the affairs of the kingdom. Quite few of the knights occupy their seats, talking with each  other, drinking and laughing, attended by ladies and page Guenevere places the apples at Lancelot's empty place and takes her seat next to Arthur. In the archways that lead into the hall, petitioners wait eating, drinking, talking among themselves. In the din, n one pays attention to the vehement arguing of the fat man and the thin man, which continues even here. The hall is burgeoning, happy center of the kingdom. But Merlin is oblivious to the lively clamor. He gazes li a lovesick puppy across the table at Morgana, who bends o whispering to a knight at the table, the young Sir Gahalt while his older brother Sir Gawain listens. Morgana notic Merlin's stare and smiles at him, and then resumes her  flirtation with Sir Gahalt, much to Merlin's annoyance. Sir Kay ushers the thin man and the fat man into the open space at the center of the table for their audience with king. They quarrel even as Kay tries to present them, and the attention of the hall gradually focuses on them. The two men talk at once, interrupting, overlapping. FAT MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brew ale, sir--from  old shoes--I am an  honest tradesman sir.  I must sell what I  produce. He won't buy  ale and he won't pay.  Pay up! He leans over  the barrel and sucks  in the vapors. The  vapors are mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is both amused and exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough!... What is a fair price for  the smell of your ale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we have come to you, sir  There's no one else who can tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it cost to get drunk on  your ale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least three shillings, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur addresses the Thin Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me three shillings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Thin Man is crestfallen, the smile gone from his face He reluctantly hands the coins to Kay, who gives them to  Arthur. Arthur tosses them in the air and lets them fall a metal plate. He hands them back to the Thin Man, who is totally confused now, as is everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the smell of your ale, the jingle  of his coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knights roar with laughter and the Fat Man and the Th Man look at each other in astonishment. Perceval lets out raucous laugh that wins him a glance of disapproval from  Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The din of the petitioners is replaced by music. It is th hour of the evening feast, and all knights are present, e Lancelot. Whole tree trunks burn in the great fireplace, lambs roast on spits in the flames. Pages run to and fro  with trays of food and wine, Perceval among them. Morgana stops beside Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I see today in the wizard's  eyes? Censure, because I enjoy a few  words with a young handsome knight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin is in agony, a bug stuck on a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, of course not. You are  young...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not jealous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear you are, and it irks me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yes, I am. I am jealous. I want  to write poems about you with  moonbeams, make the sea sing your  name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovestruck page!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh... yes, yes. Sit with me,  please... Morgana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does, laughing and in complete control. His hand  immediately slides onto her thigh. She removes it, but ho it in her hand, toying with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steamy, panting, lovestruck page.  But what good are songs and poems to  me? They are the barter of ordinary  love. A gift that reflected your  greatness is the only one worthy of  your love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin looks at her, knowing already, sad yet eager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I showed you all my conjuring  tricks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deepest secrets, the forbidden  formulas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin's thoughts have carried him far away, when he real that Arthur is addressing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, are you counselor to the  King, or to my sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some knights laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your service, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then answer me this. For years peace  has reigned in the land. Crops grow  in abundance, there is no want. Every  one of my subjects enjoys his portion  of happiness and justice, even those  whose tiresome misunderstandings we  must resolve here each day. Tell me,  Merlin: have we defeated evil, as it  seems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good and evil; there is never one  without the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where hides evil, then, in my kingdom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never where you expect it, that's  all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles softly and Arthur is puzzled. A knight speaks out, the young knight with whom Morgana was flirting. His manner is sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we have peace and justice, why is  Lancelot never with us? Why is he  always riding out on his quests? He  must know where this evil is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could there be evil within Lancelot  himself? To live above human folly,  as is his aim, is to be overly proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pays no heed even to the Queens  longing for his company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall falls silent, all eyes upon the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lashing out) What is it you would have your words  mean, Sir Gahalt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frightened, Gahalt doesn't answer. Morgana has slipped to Guenevere's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him. You are the  Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, ashen-faced, turns to Merlin for help, but he has escaped into sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Gahalt, answer the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I meant not to be angry with  you, Sir Gahalt. In the idleness  that comes with peace gossip has  bread its own evil. You merely repeat  it. Please, sir, have one of those  apples that Lancelot loves, and in  that gesture partake of its goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana picks the bowl up and as she does so, unseen by a and with a magician's dexterity, she thrusts her fingerna deep into the top apple. She gives the bowl to Guenevere, who takes it and sweeps around to where Sir Gahalt sits,  followed by Morgana. The young knight jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take one, Sir Gahalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am most honored, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is too shy to take the shiniest, most beautiful apple top, and goes for another one. Morgana giggles, and he lo at her. She looks at the apple on top and then smiles  encouragingly at him. Sir Gahalt takes it and starts eati as the Queen returns to her seat. With the third bite his is unable to breathe. His face go red and he rises to his feet, attempting to call out. He falls, dying immediately. All leap to their feet, and  Arthur rushes to the young knight. Merlin is asleep and f from human affairs. Arthur and Sir Gawain rise from the body of the young kni Sir Gawain backs away from Arthur and points at Guenevere trembling with cold rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear me, Lord Arthur, and knights  and chieftains: I charge Guenevere  with the murder of my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere, white and with a broken voice, turns to Arthur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't... I am innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to swoon and Morgana keeps her steady on her f Arthur slumps into his seat and Sir Gawain kneels before  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I champion this truth: That Queen  Guenevere murdered Sir Gahalt with  the aid of sorcery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enraged, Arthur reaches for Excalibur. But with effort he checks his impulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen will be in my charge till  a champion steps forward to fight on  her behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you, my husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur cannot look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be burnt at the stake. That  is the sentence for murder done with  magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. Lords and knights of the Round  Table, as her husband I say that  this deed was not done by Guenevere.  Who among you will champion this  truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one responds. Guenevere falls into her seat. Arthur  searches the eyes of his knights and they evade him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Caradoc! You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knight looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ector, old and feeble, weeps for Arthur. Someone spea up. It is Perceval, who kneels before the Queen. His voic is unnaturally loud, and his eyes shine with held-back te he stutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will champion you, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is overwhelmed by his own boldness. He looks around. A eyes are upon him. Guenevere smiles at him, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank you, but you are not yet a  knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will find Lancelot! He will come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval hurries from the hall. Arthur looks away, ashame and his eyes fall on Merlin, twitching and mumbling in hi sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys!... boys will be boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In full armor but for his helmet, Lancelot is seated at a small table in the shadow of a tree, eating an apple. A young girl is turning a chicken on a spit, and her moth is removing freshly-baked bread from an oven. It is very  peaceful and silent until, galloping all out, Perceval  arrives. Frantic, out of breath, he leaps from his lather horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have found you. The Queen. An apple. Tomorrow. Sir Gawain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --It must wait, child. These good  ladies, for whom I intervened once,  will honor me with a meal. I am  beholden to them now as I was when  they begged my protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women set the chicken and the bread before the gr knight, and stand back to watch him eat, flushed with  excitement. Perceval falls silent, in awe of Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stands hunched over the fireplace, staring into th flames. Guenevere paces back and forth to a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you be my champion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I am your judge, I cannot be your  champion. When I act as your King, I  cannot be your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you cannot love me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laws, my laws, must bind everyone,  high and low, or they are not laws  at all. Lancelot will come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if he cannot be found, no other  knight will champion me, though you  beseeched each and every one of them.  Why be king if there is no one you  can call loyal subject but an eager  boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hides his anguish from her. Numb with hurt, she goes t tall curtained window, and draws it open, and stands ther looking out upon the surrounding forest, silent and still beneath the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cries softly, and she whispers the name of the great  knight. EXT. EDGE OF THE FOREST, WALLS OF CAMELOT - NIGHT. A mounted knight stands motionless at the edge of the for his armor gleaming with dark lustre. It is Lancelot. His  eyes are raised to the high window, where he sees Gueneve He watches her in silence. In the high window Guenevere d the curtain and Lancelot reins back into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot has unsaddled and tethered his horse in a small  clearing. He sits, resting back against a tree. He remove his helmet; he plants his sword before him, like a cross. loosens the ties of his breastplate. He waits for day,  yawning, tired. But his eyes burn, and he closes them and nods off to sleep. A knight appears silently hovering over him. Lancelot loo up, and his eyes go wide with fear. The knight towering a him wears armor identical to his, and he raises his sword and the blade is descending upon Lancelot. Lancelot draws his sword from the ground and rolls away, but the knight' sword slices through his shoulder joint. Lancelot attempt to rise but already the knight, Lancelot's mirror image, upon him. From the ground, Lancelot parries the blow and  slashes at the opponent's knee, cutting through the joint the armor and severing the leg. The knight doesn't fall, doesn't bleed, doesn't cry out. one leg he comes forward, a horror. Lancelot is paralyzed fear. As the knight leaps upon Lancelot, Lancelot rises t meet him, impaling himself on the knight's sword below th hauberk. He throws the knight to the ground, and comes do upon him. He rips off the helmet and the breastplate. The armor is empty and Lancelot rolls over on his back, awake from the nightmare with his own sword deep in his stomach and in his hand his own helmet and breastplate, while oth parts of his armor lie strewn around him. Only then does he become conscious of the terrible pain a the shock of the truth. He grabs the hilt of his sword an draws it from his stomach. He curls up in agony, clutchin fistful of leaves to the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere, I fight against myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loses consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop blesses the field. Guenevere, numb and  disbelieving, is being led to the stake, which rises from bed of straw and wood. Arthur watches, in shock. Other kn and ladies keep their distance, watching darkly, stealing glances at Arthur, mumbling disapproval of his refusing t defend Guenevere. In battle dress, Sir Gawain rides up an down the jousting run on a snorting and powerful horse,  practicing. Perceval, in a mail doublet, waits beside a m roan, his face burning with anxiety. Guenevere is tied to the stake. All eyes watch for the  approach of her champion. Arthur goes to Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heard Lady Guenevere's request  and he said nothing. That is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur hides his pain behind a rigid mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has risen shining cruelly into Guenevere's eyes; queen is alone at the stake. Sir Gawain rides up to King  Arthur, who waits alone, separated from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lord, the sun is upon the field.  The Queen has no champion. I demand  justice, as is my right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval leaps onto his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me champion the Queen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Gawain looks at the squire with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arthur) Since no knight comes forward, I  demand justice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is in anguish. He searches the tree line for a sig of Lancelot. He looks from Guenevere at the stake to his knights watching him. He draws Excalibur. A gasp goes thr the crowd of onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, kneel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval leaps from his horse and bends his knee before t King. Arthur brings the sword down on the boy's shoulder, giving him the three strokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of God, of St. Michael,  and St. George, I make you a knight.  Rise, Sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Perceval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain shakes his head disdainfully as Perceval mounts ba into the saddle, his eyes burning with fervor. Sir Gawain and Perceval ride to opposite ends of the fiel The spectators fall silent, all staring blankly, their se dulled by the tragedy, at the uneven combatants. A cry goes up. Lancelot rides out of the forest. He rides to the King and salutes him. Arthur smiles at his old fri tears of joy in his eyes. Lancelot bows toward Guenevere rides on to where Perceval waits. Lancelot reaches out to touch Perceval's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my task to prove the Queen's  innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval cannot reply, his eyes affixed on the blood that trickles from Lancelot's hauberk. Lancelot raises his lan in salute to Gawain across the field. Gawain salutes in  answer. The two huge knights charge at each other, each man's spe tip making contact with the other's armor, and in the vio collision both are unhorsed. Lancelot is slower at gettin to his feet and drawing his sword. He is bleeding below the hauberk from his self-inflicted  wound. In the first onslaught Lancelot fights defensively, falli back. He has to toss aside his shield and hold his stomac with his shield hand. Morgana watches with Merlin. Every terrible blow of sword sword reverberates through her body pleasurable. Merlin i captivated by her cruel sensuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They swing and thrust at each other with slower but bone- crushing force, both unsteady now. Blood seeps from Lance feet, leaving awful footprints on the earth. Finally, wit daring thrust, Lancelot lifts Gawain's visor and the swor tip is before his eyes. Gawain drops his sword and shield kneels and speaks in a voice hoarse with weariness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen is innocent. I yield to  your mercy, Sir Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot collapses in a dead faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes closed, Lancelot lies on a bed, naked but for a clot across his loins. His minor wounds have been dressed, and Merlin is kneading the huge gash in his stomach, working severed flesh together. Guenevere stands on one side of t bed, Arthur on the other, both looking down upon Lancelot relieved and not daring to look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flesh on flesh. You must press on  the wound, Guenevere, hold it, and  it will begin to bind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere kneels, and at her touch Lancelot's eyes flicke open. Merlin exits, and draws Arthur away with him. Arthur is deeply tormented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, tell me. Now that Guenevere  is returned to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it my child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin appears moved by the predicaments that Arthur has face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I have a son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin stares off into the evening sky, where a lark sing high up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just yes? No mad laughter, no riddles,  nothing but a simple yes? That  frightens me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A king should be afraid, always. The  enemy is everywhere. Waiting in ambush  in the dark corridors of his castle,  on the deer paths of his forest, or  in the gray and winding paths of a  more tangled forest, in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps his skull and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot is staring into Guenevere's eyes. She opens her  shift, baring a breast with the innocence of a mother  preparing to suckle a child. She presses her breast to hi wound, her face to his chest, her arms enfolding him. She whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flesh on flesh. I will heal you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His body trembles and his eyes brim with tears. He is los

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court is assembled, for the evening feast. There is m and heavy drinking. Some knights are slouched across the  table. Lancelot, still weak, takes his seat, looking at t drunken and frivolous knights. Arthur catches it, and the smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They miss the battlefield. I think  we do too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one can still keep a sword sharp  riding out in the name of the King's  law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere cannot tear her eyes from Lancelot. He avoids h look. Arthur looks from Guenevere to Lancelot, and speaks softly to him, across her, and with stabbing directness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not easy for the young ones to  learn knightly virtues without the  hard teaching of war and quest. It  is only your example, Lancelot, that  binds them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, addressing the hall:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is the greatest quality of  knighthood? Courage? Compassion?  Loyalty? Humility? What do you say,  Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is bent close to Morgana, whispering. Only when the ha rings with laughter does he look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (then seeing he has  an audience) The greatest? They blend together  like the metals we mix to make a  good sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask for poetry. Which is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin looks from Arthur to Guenevere to Lancelot to Arth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Truth. It must be truth,  above all. When a man lies he murders  some part of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uneasy silence falls upon the feast. Guenevere and Lan cannot look at each other, and Arthur feels it. Lancelot  jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conversation and court life don't  suit me. I must take my rest in the  forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere stifles her dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't Merlin mended your wound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is deep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is about to rise to embrace him, but checks himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be sorely missed. Heal  yourself and come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exchange has become closely intimate, even though the stand apart and speak before everyone in the large hall.  Lancelot leaves. Only Guenevere cannot watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water gurgles from a rock that is captive in the roots of ancient oak. Lancelot, in armor, reclines against its tru the roots cradling him. He is perfectly still, drawing li from the vibrant, all-enfolding forest. Flower petals drift on the breeze. Trees sigh. Fox and ra sparrow and hawk, at peace with each other, watch over th knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse and rider tear through the thick undergrowth. It Guenevere. The forest races past her as she gallops towar the glade, brambles tearing at her flesh and clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot gets to his feet, tense. Guenevere dismounts and approaches. She is flushed and breathless from the wild r Her horse, left free, wanders over to his and grazes besi it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? You will destroy Arthur, and  us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves closer and he thrusts out his mailed fist to ke her away. She clutches it and presses the metal to her so tear-streaked cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law forbids it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love demands it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry with passion, she embraces the cold unmoving armor kissing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are things about love--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps back, drawing his sword. He holds it up by the b between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By my knight's sword, I swore faith--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And before he can finish she grabs the blade to push it a He holds it fast. Blood streams from her bare hands. He c prevail without cutting them deeply. He lets go of the sw and she lets it fall to the ground. She embraces his still and defeated hulk. She kisses the  metal, and sensation shoots through him, dizzying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds her in his arm, and their bodies lock together a though a trap had sprung. Their mouths meet, each devouri the other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Merlin, the King desperate, the Wizard overwhe by compassion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am alone and betrayed. By my wife,  by my beloved friend, by my knights.  And by you. Perhaps most of all by  you. For you made me, you forged  this wretched life. And like a child  tired of a toy, you toss me aside, a  babbling lecher trotting after my  sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is my destiny. I have a destiny,  too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all your powers, you are content  to be ridiculed, laughed at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My powers fade, Arthur. I resort to  cheap tricks... (with sudden enthusiasm) Yes! I enjoy every moment of my  foolishness, I join in the making of  it, so no one can betray me. But  you! You betray yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? I have lived by the oath of king  and knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You betray the boy who drew the sword,  the boy who saw the Dragon... the  Dragon who moves close by, coiling  and uncoiling, restless, looking  down, waiting for the King to be a  king...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks up and in the rolling clouds maybe, just may the form of a dragon is taking shape. Arthur draws Excali intensity animating his dead features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must do it myself. I must kill  them both. Lancelot and Guenevere.  Will you ride with me, Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot. I must not. Here I must  stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace. Merlin is on the verge of tears, his face  immediately sad and finally ancient. Arthur exits. Morgana, who has been watching from the shadows, watching from the shadows, slinks up to Merlin's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy old fool. You think yourself a  kingmaker. Ha! A meddler, more likely.  Look what a mess you've made of  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin smiles knowingly at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I? Perhaps, perhaps. I'm losing  interest, Morgana... I have helped  men--or meddled in their affairs, if  you would have it that way--since  the dawn of time. Now let them live  by their own laws. Let them stand on  their own feet. The gods of once are  gone forever, it is time for men...  Morgana, make a man out of me. Kiss  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches to touch her lips. She cradles his hand in her and doesn't allow Merlin to kiss her. She kisses his knuc and stares into his eyes, stoking his desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want. I want the  secret of true magic, how to thicken  the stuff of dreams and wishes with  the flesh of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks away, provocative, alluring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Sir Kay gallop through the forest, silently. I is not a dream.  Their armor and the hooves of their hors are muffled with pieces of cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Nature will ever see their love; the creatures of th air, tree and ground witness the final reality of their  passion and sense its unfathomable depths, singing of it a hundred languages. Lancelot and Guenevere are naked and interlocked, one being, suspended in the darkness in the of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur walks soundlessly through the trees, approaching t glade. The forest falls suddenly silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All passion spent, locked in each other's arms, Lancelot Guenevere drift off into sleep. Arthur comes upon them. He stands over them. He draws  Excalibur. Checking all emotion, he holds it above his he The ancient steel glows darkly. The lovers faces are serene and innocently beautiful. He  hesitates, tormented. His mask of anguish gives way to  determination and calm. He strikes the sword home, lettin go of it. He backs away, turns and disappears into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is red; so is the steel of Excalibur. Lancelot aw and starts at what he sees. His cry stirs Guenevere. They are horrified to see Excalibur impaled in the ground betw their entwined bodies. It has pierced their union without grazing their flesh. They leap up and back away, unable t speak at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he kill us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has given up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kneels before the sword, embracing the hilt to her br

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King without his sword, the land  without a king...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are to blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot stumbles into the forest, berserk with guilt. He rages against a small tree, crying out, and he rips its r from the ground, the terrible tearing and renting the sym of his own inner torment. Guenevere sinks to the ground next to Lancelot's empty ar and his abandoned sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin and Morgana descend winding steps cut out of rock. The only light comes from the glow of Merlin's staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Arthur built the castle, I carved  out a place for myself, where I could  laugh or sleep, and no one would  bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People make you laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans close to her ear, whispering into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know how close they live  to the edge of delight or disas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is about to kiss her when he slips. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happiness or horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass through jaws of stalactites and stalagmites. Me cracks his staff whip-like and a ball of fire billows up  from the tip and illuminates a cave wildly veined and  filigreed with minerals and crusted with growths of cryst The light goes out but the malachite and the gold, the qu diamond and beryllium burn dully. He turns to her, sudden tall and unstooped, younger, sleek and evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the folds of the earth where the  forces that hold the world together  are more alive, my power is strongest.  Here I will possess you, as a man  possesses a woman. And the god, the  eunuch, the mule that I was, will be  no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps her up into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are truly magnificent!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flattery! Do you think I am ignorant  of your stupid little games? Preying  on you weakness of others. That's  your power, a petty evil. Mine is  great. Great plans. Impossible dreams.  Laughable endings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He deposits her on bare rock. He kisses her. She pushes h away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, the powers of Summoning, the  true Name of the charms of Doing and  Undoing. Show me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't. You would misuse such power.  I have paid enough for you, and I  will have you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans forward and kisses his ear and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make magic, my foolish wizard. For  our love. Weave a marvelous room  around us, a room worthy of our  coupling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws closer, kissing him deeply. He breathes heavily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? You must desire it  for me to weave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walls of shining crystals, burning  with red fire, furnishings of metals  and jewels never seen by man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana falls silent as Merlin raises a hand, majesticall intoning a harsh repetitive charm. The mineral veins of t cave begin to glow and fog seeps out from them enveloping the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desire it and it will be as you  desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana burns with intensity. Merlin utters a formula and the fog coalesces around them into the shimmering presenc of crystal walls, fountains raining jewels, flowers made scented air, a bed of glass shot with light and covered w skins of animals dead before the time of man, goblets of  ruby, tapestries woven of golden hair. She reaches out to touch the wall and her hand plunges through the unmateria illusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a semblance. You disappoint  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins lacing up her loosened gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch the walls. Come close to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does, a mad hope in her eyes. She kisses his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it, Merlin, the deepest secret.  Fix it with the charm of Making, for  our endless pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He utters the ancient charm, Morgana listening closely,  memorizing it. The illusion is all of a sudden solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs her hand across the hard crystal surface, her ey gleaming. From outside the wondrous room they can be seen to embrac He carries her to the magical bed where he makes love to  her, as they disappear from view in its effulgent light. She comes out through the crystal door, burning with evil intent. She turns to watch him asleep in the bed. She utters the charm of Summoning learnt from Merlin, and the room melts into an eddying carmine fog. Within it, Me struggles to awaken from the torpor of love, alarmed. Outside, Morgana utters the charm of Making and the gaseo mass begins to crystallize. Inside, Merlin is rising to his feet, breathing the red f his movements slowing to a standstill, his mouth opening a scream of horror. The cloud has metamorphosed into a magnificent cluster of red crystals.  Morgana peers into its facets and there sh sees, in fragments, Merlin's terror... an eye, the gaping mouth, a clawing hand--as he is entombed in the stone. Sh laughs in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by forest, the spires and battlements of Camel rise under black storm clouds. Arthur and Kay ride back t the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great hall is in gloom. Few knights are in attendance the table. Some sleep off last night's wine. Arthur approaches, hagg searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has no one seen Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knights look up; those who meet Arthur's reddened eyes sh their heads. Arthur leaves. A knight whispers to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see? The King was without  Excalibur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echoing in the vaulted corridors outside the hall, the  knight's whisper stabs Arthur. The words now seem borne on the whistling wind and follow the King wherever he goes in search of Merlin. He comes u a knight seducing a lady in a dark corner by the chapel d his hand under her gown. Arthur notes the sacrilege in  silence, and continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind keens. Thunder rolls overhead. Arthur enters his bedchamber. He sits by the empty fireplace, a broken man. Feminine hands light on his shoulders. He starts. He look up. It is Morgana. He smiles and grasps her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll weep for you, brother, for a  King must not weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes around and she kneels in front of him. Before h can talk she silences him with a tender caress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what Guenevere's maids  have whispered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That when the King returned from  battle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins untying the laces of his metal thigh and shin  guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Guenevere would unlace his armor  and massage the burns where metal  rubbed on flesh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is stripping his legs naked, gently touching the fles with her fingertips. He stares off, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She would prepare a bath for you,  mixing special ointment in the  water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's eyes brim with tears. Morgana weeps, embracing h knees. He rests his hand gently upon her head, choked wit remembrance, soothing her. But as she weeps, she incants charm. Arthur looks down upon her, and the woman who looks up at him is Guenevere, a Guenevere with cold ice eyes. He is m weak by desire and weakened further by magic. He holds he face adoringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere! You are--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Don't speak. A thousand words, a  hundred thousand words, would only  be prologue to the truth that must  be. That you, King, and I, your Queen,  beget a son to bond our love and to  strengthen our weak kingdom with a  successor. Come, my lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws him to the floor and upon her body, holding him tightly to himself. Arthur trembles with excitement, path in his desperate passion. As he takes her, she shudders, losing control of the char and her features change till once again "Guenevere" is  Morgana. She holds him in a tight embrace so that he may see her. She whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon flows in my blood to meet  your seed. And already I bear him  who will be King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur wrenches himself away so he can see her, her arms  still around his neck. He looks down upon her, aghast,  incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could easily kill you, brother.  But I want you to live to see our  son be King. In me, the blood of  Cornwall will have its revenge; in  me, the blood of Uther will show its  dark side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She presses her thumbs into his neck and he faints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana, with a small party, rides away from the castle  through the lashing storm, till they are taken from sight the folds of the forest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightening forks across the sky, illuminating the interio The chapel has been transformed into a place of satanic  worship. Held up and surrounded by hooded figures, Morgan lies on the altar, her pregnant belly huge; and her featu are fierce with passionate intensity. She writhes in the  pangs of childbirth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, all of you. Through my  own body I have nurtured him with my  potions. I made him. I alone can  give him life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur enters, pale and haunted. Mass is being celebrated and some knights are present. Those not asleep whisper to each other about the King. The sound of an approaching st is heard. As the priest raises the chalice to consecrate the wine.  Arthur comes down the aisle and steps onto the altar. He  reaches out to grasp the chalice from the priest's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana holds aloft her beautiful newborn baby, his body  glistening in a flash of lightening. She is triumphant. INT. CHAPEL, CAMELOT - NIGHT. A bolt of lightening strikes the chalice, rocking the cha and Arthur is knocked back violently. Rain lashes in through the shattered window upon the terr knights. They and the priest back away. Arthur is left al He rises and goes to the chalice, which is bent and crack He kneels before it. Steam hisses up as rain falls on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun streams in. Many of the knights are in attendance, in full armor. Ladies and pages watch from dark corners. Arthur addresse the fellowship. He holds the cracked chalice in his hands. He burns with new-found fervor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will ride the labyrinths of the  forest, to the very root of his soul,  to the very ends of the earth, to  find the secret that will redeem us  from the evil that has fallen upon  us, and make this chalice, and  ourselves, whole again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain rises and draws his sword in salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ride forth in the name of  that quest, and commit my strength  and my soul to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval, Kay and a few others draw their swords and touc their lips to the blades in oath. Sunbeams splash off the armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the fellowship draw their swords in imitation but the resolution within them is not strong. Arthur come forward to Gawain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain, a dreadful fear is upon me,  that we may never meet again, that  the fellowship will be no more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces Gawain, tears in his eyes. He turns to Percev and Perceval kneels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will find the secret or die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur kisses the young knight's brow. Then he turns to K

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, I know your heart yearns to go,  but I am prisoner to my duties, and  you must be to yours, at my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Kay watch the knights file out till the hall i empty, the harsh song of their armor growing distant.

dialogues.speaker: A LEGEND APPEARS
dialogues.text: "For nine years they searched. Morgana's power grew in th land."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a leaden sky, Gawain drives his horse through swirl snow. He comes upon a mounted knight who is frozen in his tracks. He brushes the snow from the man's face. The froz features belong to Caradoc. He slowly continues on his wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangling from the branches of a dead tree are a dozen dea knights of the Round Table, crows pecking at the rotting  flesh in the chinks of armor. Perceval rides up, cries ou in horror, and spurs his horse away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rotting carcasses of sheep. The crops blackened and  withered on the stalk. Hungry peasants head for a distant hill.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HILLSIDE, MOORS
dialogues.text: A giant head has been carved out of an outcrop of rock, i stone mouth gaping toward the sky. People are congregated around the mouth. Peasants and far they are wild with excitement, responding to drums throbb and bagpipes wailing. They watch Morgana, who is surrounded by knights in dark  armor. At her side is an angelic boy of eight, his eyes c as his mother's. Morgana is more beautiful than ever, in  flowing druidic robes, the gossamer silk clinging to her  sweat-drenched body. She is standing by the deep hole which forms the giant's  open mouth. It is covered by a tooth-like grating acting a drain for the blood of human sacrifices made there. Bef her is Gawain, chained and struggling against five strong men who hold him. Morgana lifts a dagger and plunges it i Gawain's chest. The fountain of blood that gushes from th great knight's body drives the crowd into a frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intoning) The blood of this knight will feed  the god in the earth, he is weak  with hunger, and he will be made  strong by this blood. Then he will  plant his seed, and the land will be  fertile once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain, his blood flowing from him and into the giant's m looks up in anguish. His bellowing voice is echoed and  amplified by the hollow beneath the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, forgive me. I die without  the secret. I have failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain's death cry and the din of the ritual carries to  Perceval's ears as he wanders through the wasteland. He d down his visor and spurs his horse forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gallops toward the giant's head. He checks his sword a lowers his lance. The knight charging forward on his war horse is an awesom sight, but the crowd around the giant's mouth is strangel unfrightened. Morgana is excited; she turns to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mordred, a true prize for the  giant. The lamb rides into our jaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval is galloping toward them when the ground gives w beneath the horse, and he and the animal plunge into a pi The cheering crowd rushes to the edge of the trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mordred) You must kill him, for this knight  is dear to your father. You must do  it and learn to enjoy your father's  pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her knights drag Perceval, unarmed, into Morgana's presen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you found what you search for?  Have you found what Arthur seeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval doesn't answer, defiant and hiding his fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't, or you would be smiling  now in the face of death. Your quest  is an impossible one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it might be impossible makes it  all the more necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fool! (to the men holding  Perceval) Uncover him. I'll show you the mystery  of life. It's death... (to Mordred) Do it, Mordred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding Perceval by his limbs and hair, the men force him down on the bloody grating, drawing back his head, exposi his throat. Morgana kneels by his head, and draws the boy beside her. She holds the tip of the dagger to Perceval's neck and takes Mordred's hand and wraps it around the han Perceval is choked with fear, his heart pounding in his  throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel the life through the dagger,  child. It belongs to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy looks up at his mother. The vein in Perceval's ne pushes against the dagger's point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel it, Mother. I will give his  blood to the giant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy raises the dagger, and hesitates just a bit. Perc resigns himself bravely. He looks the child calmly in the eye. Mordred brings down the blade without strength, just piercing the skin with the tip. He lets go of the dagger, afraid now of his mistake. The dagger clatters to the grating and slips away down th drain, before Morgana can retrieve it. She rages against  Mordred. In the confusion, Perceval tears loose, the men  holding him slipping on the blood-wet stone. Perceval runs through the crowd. Immediately, lance lower a knight is upon him. Perceval leaps toward him, catching the lance in his hand, and pulling down the rider with it He jumps the rider and draws the knight's sword. Whirling the lance and cutting the air with the sword, he keeps ba the other knights for a moment, giving him time to see hi chance. He leaps onto the riderless horse and charges off through the crowd. He reins in abruptly, the horse rearin He is wary of the ground before him; there could be a hid pit. But there is no time to think. Knights and men on fo are rushing him. He spurs forward into a gallop, the hors striding mightily And its hind leg sinks into a pit, the  animal losing its gait. But the momentum carries the hors forward, and it recovers from the stumble. Perceval gallops away. Morgana is enraged. She shakes Mordred by the hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't kill him! You didn't kill  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But suddenly she begins kissing him tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, sweet boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just stands there emotionless, the dead center of her  turbulent passions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval gallops down a trail. The black-armored knights Morgana chase him. Perceval reins into deep cover alongside the trail. The  pursuers thunder past and the sound of hooves recedes.  Perceval checks his newly found sword, slashes the air to feel the weapon's balance. He re-sheathes it. He pats the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll become good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off again, into the patchless forest of dead tr He is suddenly set upon by a wildman who, swinging a smal uprooted tree, knocks him off his horse. Perceval crashes the ground and before he can use his sword the wildman ha knocked it out of his hand. It is Lancelot, demented, who furiously rains battering b on Perceval's armor, bellowing with rage. All that Percev can do is attempt to avoid the blows. Lancelot addresses  Perceval as if the young knight were Lancelot himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Lancelot, in  your iron tomb? Still trying to save  the world? (He hammers blows  into Perceval's armor) The best... the bravest... the  greatest... fool that ever lived.  Now the world rots. Death is king of  the earth. And it is you who make it  so, Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Perceval can speak, Lancelot disappears again into the forest, his eyes blank, as though his encounter with young knight had never happened. A knot of pain, Perceval pulls himself up. He tries to ri into the saddle. He is too hurt to do it. He starts off o foot, slowly, leading the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very dark and Perceval has to feel his way. He comes to the edge of a stream. He kneels to drink, and the horse drinks beside him. Then he rests back on his he brooding, too tired to rise. He lowers his eyes, staring into the dark water, defeated empty. Before him in the water a long thin bar of light appears. looks at it amazed. Voices are heard singing very far awa He reaches out to touch the long strip of light but his h just disturbs the water. It is a reflection. The strip gr wider and the ethereal music is closer. Perceval looks up. The strip of light is before him,  suspended, thirty feet above. It continues to grow wider. drawbridge is being slowly lowered, allowing a powerful l to escape from within. Perceval is terrified. In pain, he slowly rises into the  saddle, ready to gallop off; but fascinated, hypnotized b the sight, he cannot, and he stays and watches. The dim outline of a castle becomes visible as the drawbr is lowered across the water to the ground at his feet. At the center of the blast of light coming from the castle,  Perceval can make out a burning chalice. The music swells a terrifying pitch, searing the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sight of the chalice, Perceval masters his fear. B in light and music, he spurs the horse forward onto the  drawbridge. Once he is on it, the bridge begins to rise. Unsure of it footing and blinded by the light, the horse becomes skitt and Perceval has to struggle to control it. He dismounts lead it, but the horse is terrified, rears up and jumps o the bridge, which continues to rise, drawn up by unseen h Perceval hesitates, then advances down the sloping drawbr into the castle courtyard. All details are bleached out b the blinding light. The chalice appears suspended in spac and now the figure of a man can be glimpsed standing behi it. Enchanting music from unseen singers grows and weaves.  Perceval looks back to see the drawbridge slowly closing, trapping him inside. He approaches the figure, his courage ebbing. Hands cuppi the chalice, it speaks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the secret of the chalice?  Who does it serve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval doesn't understand. He glances back again. The  drawbridge is nearly closed. Terror seizes him. Panicked, puzzled, baffled, he backs away. He scrambles u the drawbridge desperate to reach the top before it close He claws his way up till his hand grasps the top. He heav himself through the narrow closing slit which is about to crush him. He screams, and with a final effort he wriggle free and topples over crashing into the water below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. The drawbridge thunders shut, the last thin  strip of light disappearing; and now he is surrounded onl by the silence of the forest. Where there was a castle, now there is darkness. Perceval wades through the water. He has crossed the stream and al he can see and feel are tree trunks. The castle has  disappeared. He is utterly defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chalice. The secret was in my  grasp. I let it slip, afraid for  myself. A question was asked. I didn't  understand. I didn't try. I failed...

dialogues.speaker: A LEGEND APPEARS
dialogues.text: "Nine years passed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping water is steadily encrusting the crystal with  limestone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead knights lay on biers. The once glorious seat of powe is falling into decay. Few are in attendance around the t Agitated, Kay enters and goes to Arthur, who is worn and  haggard, and aged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son Mordred is at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur comes alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't recognize him. You were trapped  by Morgana's sorcery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring off) ...Gawain and Perceval, Bors and  Bohort, Caradoc and Ector, and all  the others--lost to me. Only the  echo of their voices remains in this  empty hall. All I have left is the  memory of their fellowship. Echoes  and memories. I am a ghost of the  King that once was... (he turns to Kay and  with sudden harshness) ...Mordred is real, alive, my own  flesh and blood. I will see him, I  must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drawbridge lowers slowly, and Arthur moves away from and the other knights, and advances across it. Rooks wheel over the dead trees of the forest that surrou Camelot. A group of armed men waits at the edge of the fo One steps forward, a huge knight in black armor, the meta defining and exaggerating the powerful musculature of his body. He is Mordred, a young man of eighteen, and of  extraordinary beauty. A page follows ten steps behind him bearing an enormous spear, its points hooded. Arthur stop at the edge of the drawbridge, the huge knight a few step from him. Kay, ready for anything, moves halfway across t drawbridge. Mordred kneels on one knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise, Mordred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to claim what is mine,  Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recognize you only as my son, no  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his tone is scathing) And you are the great King? The lords  have rebelled. Invaders attack the  coasts. Crops don't grow. There is  nothing but plague and hunger in the  land. Only I am feared. I will be  king. You may have lost Excalibur,  but I have found my own weapon of  power. There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the huge lance. The page pulls a string and hood drops, revealing a diabolically sharp spear tip, its metal glinting menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very spear that pierced the side  of Christ as he died on the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mordred is thrown off by the doubt Arthur has cast. Arthu looks upon his son, desperately trying to read him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot offer you the land, only my  love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I offer only this, Father. To  commit with passion and pleasure all  the evils that you failed to commit,  as man and king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur goes forward to embrace his son, a desperate attem Mordred recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will embrace only in battle.  Father, and I will touch you only  with the blade of my spear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will muster a great force of  knights, and I will return to fight  for what is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and re-enters the castle, the drawbridge pulled immediately behind him. He is hunched over, broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asleep in the saddle, Perceval rides across burnt and  smoldering fields. The horse walks aimlessly; it is the s animal, mangy and old. A hoard of children in filthy rags closes in on him, begging, pulling at the horse's trappin He bolts awake and reins away. His eyes are red and fever Wild hope grips him when he sees a glinting light by a  farmhouse. He spurs the horse forward into a gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps from the saddle and a terrified woman backs away Perceval plunges his hand into the source of light. It is nothing but the reflection of the dying sun in a bucketfu of water. Perceval covers his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illusions. I will never find it  again... I am sorry, woman, that I  frightened you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peasants have emerged, surrounding him, and they hold axe and pitchforks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good woman, do you have any food?  Some water?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little we had, we gave to  Mordred's knights. He has taken this  land. Tell the King that now we must  look to Mordred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we will give you some water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least ten peasants encircle Perceval and he is too  exhausted to put up a fight. They grab him and carry him  away. Other peasants pull his horse to the ground, and on raises and ax to kill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They throw Perceval down an escarpment and he rolls into fast-moving water. He is swept downstream and thrown  ferociously against the rocks in the stream bed, crying o in pain.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: The water is deeper and Perceval is dragged under by the  weight of his armor. He struggles desperately to shed it, half drowning. Exhausted, he pulls himself up onto the muddy shore besid rotting sheep carcass, and around him, the daylight dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragged and bruised, lifeless, he stares into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lost my horse, my armor, my  sword. I have lost my way. I have  lost my strength. I have lost  everything... I will not lose hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light bursting through the trees shines on the mud,  wordless, harmonies sound somewhere in the forest. Percev sets off toward the source. The burning light blasts into his face but he doesn't fli The chorus builds in power. Before him, a drawbridge lowe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps onto the bridge and walks in. He crosses the  courtyard as the drawbridge closes behind him. All detail of the castle are bleached out by the searing light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps onto the bridge and walks in. He crosses the  courtyard as the drawbridge closes behind him. All detail of the castle are bleached out by the searing light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading for the source of the light he ascends what seem be a staircase. He enters a hall where the chalice stands suspended, burning with light, and the mysterious music s and grows. Perceval approaches the diaphanous and featureless Figure who stands over the chalice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does it serve?
