dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have waited long for you. Once you  almost saw, but fear blinded you.  Why am I served from the chalice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you and the land are one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am wasting away and I cannot die.  And I cannot live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and the land are one. Drink from  the chalice. You will be reborn and  the land with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval cups his hands around the chalice to lift it. Bu they close on nothing, and he draws back. The Figure's ha although insubstantial, grasp Perceval's and appear to ho his hands around the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval begins to kneel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my lord and King. You are  Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blinding light vanishes, the music drifts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval falls to his knees before Arthur and he holds th chalice, now whole again, up to the King. It fills with b from within and Arthur takes it from Perceval. He drinks. And having done so, he seems to become younger and to gro in strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know how empty was my soul  until it was filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Kay stands by the vast fireplace where a small fire b and only now looks up and is aware of Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval, you have returned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready my knights for battle; they  will ride with their King once more.  I have lived through others far too  long! Lancelot carried my honor and  Guenevere my guilt. My knights have  fought my causes. Mordred carries my  sins. Now, at last, I will rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur at the head of a small force of knights, their arm shining beneath the moon, gallops through the land. Where hooves thunder, the ground becomes alive with sprouts and tendrils, and bare trees start to bud, and grasses to blo the power of Nature exploding into life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old nun approaches the doors, upon which someone is  pounding loudly. She opens the peephole. It is Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away. No man is allowed beyond  these doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old nun is amazed and starts pushing open the many bo mumbling and agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads the King, his footsteps ringing in the silent  cloister, past the doors to the cells. His armor is wet w dew and it shines with a dull and deep luster. Nuns whisp at his transit. She opens the door to a cell and Arthur s inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles flicker on a small altar before which a nun is  praying. She turns to see who has entered. It is Guenever older, thin with self-denial, all the more beautiful. She looks up at the majestic figure who stands before her. Sh nearly swoons. He helps her to her feet, and words rush f deep within him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere, accept my forgiveness,  and put your heart to rest. We have  suffered to long. I have always loved  you, and I still love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved you much, as King, and  sometimes as husband, but one cannot  gaze too long at the sun in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, my wife, if you can. I  was not born to live a man's life,  but to be the stuff of future memory.  The fellowship was a brief beginning,  a fair time that cannot be forgotten;  and because it will not be forgotten,  that fair time may come again. Now  once more I must ride with my knights  to defend what was, and the dream of  what could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have kept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws back the covers of her pallet, and there is  Excalibur. Arthur is overwhelmed by emotion; he can barel speak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never dared to hope all these years  that it was in your keeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels before her and kisses her thigh. She gazes off, remembering the life of long ago. He rises and looks off  into her eyes, unable to find the words; he finally does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have often thought that in the  hereafter of our lives, when I owe  no more to the future and can be  just a man, that we may meet, and  you will come to me and claim me as  yours, and know that I am your  husband. It is a dream I have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Excalibur by the hilt and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nuns scatter before him in awe and terror. He strides forward, Excalibur in hand. He stops and tests its balanc and he draws force from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guenevere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excalibur gleams in the sunlight. Arthur holds it high, a the head of a small force of knights under the banner of Dragons. Kay and Perceval ride at his side. Plumed helmet shields blazing with armorial colors, pennants flying in clean wind from their lances; it is a brave sight. The tr are in blossom and dandelion fluff billows up at their  passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's group comes to a halt. Two knights and a few squ galloping from the opposite direction rein in before the  King. The knights draw their swords in homage, and the ol one addresses Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only me and my son. All other  knights of the dukedom have rallied  to Mordred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur smiles hiding the hurt. He points to an open pit, huge devastation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What horror is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mordred, sir. He digs for precious  metals, with which he buys the loyalty  of men at arms, binding them to his  side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a clear night and the sky blazes with stars. A cres moon casts its silvery light upon Arthur, who wanders fro his camp alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops in the ancient circle of Druidic stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am outnumbered ten to one by  Mordred's forces. Merlin, I need you  at my side as you were once, my  friend, to give me courage. There  are no war tricks that will fool  Mordred. He was weaned on blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falls on his knees in front of the stone, tired, betwe thinking and dreaming, and he bangs his mailed fist again it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than I ever did, I need you  now. Where are you, Merlin? Is it  true that Morgana has trapped you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The veins of crystal glow darkly, and the hammering of  Arthur's fist upon the stone is dimly echoed here. In the red crystal, fragments of Merlin can be glimpsed, trapped frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur slips off into sleep. The stones around him distor He speaks softly, but then though the words continue, his lips are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If only you could be at my side,  Merlin, to see me wield Excalibur  once more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crystal is cracking, shards falling to the cave floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is still on his knees, and he sits back, looking u But the atmosphere is different, within a dream, and the  stones of the henge loom larger over him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place? It is rumored  Merlin, that you drew your power  from these circles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand ruffles the King's hair. He turns, and is face to  face with Merlin, standing over him. Arthur looks at him  without surprise, as though the intervening years never w Merlin begins to laugh his hideous giggle. Arthur rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. You'll wake the men, and they  must fight tomorrow for their very  lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I have heard noises and echoes  through the stones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place, Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is like a tree. The roots of the  stones spread out across the land  and they draw on the thoughts and  actions of men. Like sap those human  matters course through the stones  feeding the stars that are the leaves  of the tree. And the stars whisper  back to men the future course of  events. (becoming passionate) But the earth is being torn apart,  its metals stolen, and the balance  is broken and the lines of power no  longer converge. In fact, I nearly  didn't make it in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He limps affectedly and stretches with exaggerated pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been these many years?  Is it true that Morgana--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Stories... You brought me back.  Your love brought me back. Back to  where you are now, in the land of  dreams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a dream? Tell me, Merlin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin smiles, turns and leaves, heading for Arthur's cam giggling. Arthur starts off after him and awakens from th dream when he walks into one of the stones. It takes him moment to realize that Merlin has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries away toward the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shakes Kay awake, and as the faithful knight comes out of a deep sleep, he clutches Arthur's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, will I live...? (he shakes away the  dream) ...I was dreaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He spoke to me. He said I would  fight bravely tomorrow. I have never  dreamed of Merlin before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed of him too... Merlin lives!  He lives in our dreams now, in that  dark and shadowy place that is as  strong and real as this more solid  one. He speaks to us from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cape flowing, Merlin sweeps between Mordred's war tents, in the logic of dreams, unseen by the guards. He passes a tent where the huge shadow of Mordred is thrown on the ca as he sharpens the blade of a fearsome spear. He enters a tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is stunningly beautiful in her sleep. Merlin leans ov her lovely body, kisses her softly on the lips, and waits for her to awaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have returned, enchantress. You  are beautiful, magnificent. Have you  used up all the magic you stole from  me to keep yourself young? Have you  any magic left to do battle with  Merlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises from her sleeping body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You provoke me, Merlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's behind that beauty? A wizened,  cold-hearted snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin steps back, grandiose and melodramatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a snake about to strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am the staff that drives the  snake back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers the staff with dreamlike slowness and she slink right up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burning with the fire of desire, I  am the flames that consume the staff  to ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winds her fluttering hands around the staff, and the  shadows they cast upon the tent give the illusion of lick flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the cloudburst that quenches  the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the desert, where water  disappears--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I am the sea, which covers the  desert forever under its weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I am the fog and mists that rise  up from the sea, escaping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs at her cleverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog and mist! You couldn't be that.  You don't have enough magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana tosses and mutters in her tormented dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I have the desire and I have the  magic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merlin, huge, magnetic, enfolds Morgana in his cape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are mine at last. I am the sea  and you will never escape me. Fog  and Mist...!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he laughs at her, suffocating her. Morgana begins cha the charm of Making, desperate--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and she finishes uttering it in her sleep. Her eyes spr open, and vapors issue from her gaping mouth. She screams and the fog gushes out filling the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog billows out of the tent, spreading through the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fog is rising, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and goes out with the lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is fogbound, the campfires yellow smudges within it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the lieutenant) My mother has a sense for such things.  She said there would be no fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mordred enters his mother's tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mordred enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgana, withered, old, lies dead in the bed, wisps of sm rising from within her ruptured body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, with Kay and Perceval, canters through the white  fog. They are flanked by a phalanx of knights in silver a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay, you will lead the attack.  Perceval, you will stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay draws his sword in salute, elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be cautious, my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spurs forward, while Arthur reins to a halt, watching disappear. Perceval and a few knights stay behind and sur the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this battle there is one thing I  must do, that no one else can. Find  Mordred and kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, the horrible din of joined battle. In the swirling fog, clash of arms follows clash of arms. There is confusion, for each knight is unable to see if h is fighting friend or foe until they are upon each other. The battle becomes a series of vicious duels, a knight in silver armor against a knight in black-burnished armor, j glimpsed in the fog that is alive with the clang of sword shield, the pounding of hooves, the cries of the dying. Squires drag away their wounded knights, their young face pale at the sight of the carnage. Kay is unhorsed but picks himself up and mounts a riderle horse, rejoining the combat although he is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is full day, and the fog blinds with its painful glare Arthur with Perceval at his side rides through the fog,  searching. Perceval takes up a challenge against the King He unhorses this opponent, piercing him with his lance. H returns to the King's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are too many on Mordred's side.  We cannot hold out much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay is glimpsed fighting on foot, hurt, barely holding hi own, but then the sight is hidden in the fog. Kay overcomes his opponent and stops to catch his breath. is amazed by what he sees. A knight, in old, battle-scarr armor whose pieces don't match, cuts down the knights in  black in foray after foray, wheeling and turning in a  brilliant and ruthless spectacle of martial arts. He figh without a shield, a lance in his left hand and sword in h right. Kay moves away in search of Arthur. Arthur and Perceval watch the lone knight meting out deat with such terrible beauty, weaving in and out of the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can be no other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot?... It is Lancelot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spurs his horse forward to join him, but Perceval is q to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my lord. We seek Mordred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay rises onto a fresh horse and gallops away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Perceval ride alone, the accompanying knights  gone, the dying and the dead and the crazed horses all ar them. Squires are carrying Kay upon his shield. He is dead. Art leaps to the ground and reaches out to touch his face, an closes his eyes. He stifles his tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anyone seen Lancelot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies over there, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur rushes off, Perceval following on horseback. Lancelot is mortally wounded, blood flowing from his abdo his eyes open but his gaze dead. Arthur falls to his side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squire! Here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is no one now except the dead and wounded, and  Perceval, who dismounts to watch over the King, sword dra Desperate, Arthur stops the wound with his hand. Lancelot eyes are sightless, but tears spill from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancelot, I will save you... Don't  die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears off a piece of his tunic and staunches the wound with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My salvation is to die a Knight of  the Round Table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are that and much more. You are  its greatest knight, you are what is  best in men. Now we will be together--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --It is the old wound, that has been  opened. I have always known it would  be the gateway to my death, for it  has never healed. Let my heart do  its job, my King, and pump me empty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur takes Lancelot in his arms and rests his lips agai the knight's brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a death whisper) Guenevere, has she come to you, is  she Queen again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies, closing his eyes, unable to look at Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is, Lancelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boyish smile settles over the features of Lancelot's fa and he dies. Arthur holds him to his breast, his eyes shu tight. A strong wind rises. Perceval kneels beside Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fog is lifting. Only we remain  alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Perceval rise, and as far as they can see acro the green hills that roll down to the sea lies the afterm of the massacre. Hacked bodies, abandoned armor, steaming horse carcasses, everything still. The murmur of the dyin is carried on the wind to the soft roar of the sea. The  squires have fled the scene of horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for Mordred. Where is Mordred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsewhere on the battlefield, Mordred searches the dead,  accompanied only by his lieutenant, who turns over the bo of Arthur's knights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Arthur's knights reaches out blindly for help. Mor crushes his skull underfoot. The shaft of his huge lance caked with blood, as are his hands. Arthur and Perceval see Mordred and his lieutenant, and t King restrains Perceval from going forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Perceval. Now it is time for me  to raise my sword. (he bellows out) Mordred, prepare to meet your death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shield on his left arm, and Excalibur in his right, he st toward Mordred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wait for you, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mordred advances forward, the huge spear in both hands an parallel to the ground. Arthur goes straight for him, shield ready to receive the blow. Mordred keeps walking, his arms now tensed back and ready to strike. Once they are within weapon's reach of each other, Mordre dashes forward and thrusts the spear. It glances off Arth shield, slides under his hauberk and penetrates the King' body, and so powerful was the blow that the blade pierces him right through. Mortally wounded, Arthur's scream of pain becomes a horri war cry, and he drives himself forward with all the stren he has along the spear shaft almost to Mordred's hands.  Mordred is knocked back and to the ground and Arthur pres down on him, the butt of the spear pinning Mordred. Arthu lifts Excalibur. Mordred attempts to free himself, as the blade of Excalibur descends upon him and cuts through met flesh and bone. Mordred's head falls to the ground, rolling away. Mordred's lieutenant flees. Perceval races to Arthur's si and supports the King who has fallen on his knees. Arthur speaks through the pain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw the spear from me. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval holds the King tight to himself with one arm, wh with the other he draws the shaft through and out of Arth body. Arthur sags but doesn't fall. Perceval begins to re his armor to get at the gaping wounds. The King speaks sl softly, from outside his own pain-wracked body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one thing left to do...  Excalibur... And you must do it,  Perceval. Leave my wounds, I command  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Take Excalibur. Find a pool of  calm water and throw the sword into  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval, stunned by the command, doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obey me, Perceval. You must act for  me. It is my last order as your King.  Do it, and be back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval picks up the sword, mounts his horse and rides  inland. Arthur watches him go, struggling with the pain,  still kneeling, and then his head falls to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval steps through tall reeds to the edge of a pool. cannot bring himself to throw Excalibur into the water. H examines the blade, and it is haloed with a faint iridesc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too precious a thing. I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs away from the water and hides the sword in the r and starts back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval dismounts, rushing to kneel at the King's side.  Arthur looks up, calm and intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you threw it in, what did you  see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I saw nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King looks at him with piercing power. Perceval blurt it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My King, I couldn't do it. Excalibur  cannot be lost. Other men--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --By itself it is only a piece of  steel. Its power comes from he who  wields it. For now there is no one.  Do as I have ordered!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval leaves once more. The daylight is failing, the s is near the horizon over the sea, bursting through clouds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the sword and looks at it for a long time.  Finally, with great misgiving, he hurls it into the middl of the pool. As Excalibur is about to touch the water a  woman's hand reaches and grasps it by the hilt. It holds sword aloft for a moment and then draws it under. Perceval backs away from the pool stunned by the marvel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval returns to the King, terribly excited, shouting  from his horse:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Arthur isn't there. Perceval looks around him, he doe understand. He sees a trail of blood. He spurs his horse follows the trail down to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a trail of blood and prints upon the sand left b man crawling. Perceval follows them toward the sea. He looks around,  searching, terribly distraught. Where the blood and prints cease, there are many footprin coming from and returning into the sea. Perceval looks ou across the waves. He sees a sailing vessel rising on the swell. On its deck can make out the distant figure of Arthur, lying surround by women, their gossamer robes rippling in the wind. The hovers on the horizon and the ship is heading for it. He gallops into the waves until his horse will go no furt calling out with all his strength, a futile attempt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! Will you return?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun slips below the horizon. Night is falling, and th wind whips the wavecrests. He turns from the sea and wade back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the knights of the Round Table  are dead. Excalibur is returned.  Arthur is gone. Maybe he lives, maybe  he will return...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at the edge of the water. In the uncertain light sky and sea become one. He draws the chalice out of a pou on his saddle, and he holds it up before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only I remain, and this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind swirls and whistles mysteriously in the hollow o the cup. Music grand and melancholic grows from it. The  chalice, etched in starlight, is the last thing that is t from sight in the enfolding darkness.
